description:
One thing that really stands out in San Francisco is just how many parks and green spaces there are. Yerba Buena is a particularly cool park because it's a little refuge to all the busy offices around. 

There is an outstanding MLK memorial that I highly suggest you walk through. My favorite overall area of these gardens though comes as no surprise to those who know me: The food. There is a restaurant called Samovar Tea Lounge that's surrounded by flowers with epic food and a nice view of everything. It's now firmly in the "must-visit" category for me. 

There are public restrooms and drinking fountains making it a nice rest stop if you're in the area as well. 

All in all just a nice relaxing, great urban park.
author: Adam S.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is my oasis when I'm in the downtown/SOMA areas. With great architectural views of surrounding buildings, cultural institutions like the MOMA, Contemporary Jewish or other smaller museums, YBG is beautiful - a soul satisfying experience.
Often times there are ethnic festivals and concerts held here which provide free entertainment.
Otherwise, it's just great to have some green space away from the shopping crowds where I can take a deep breath and breathe. When it's a sunny day, there's nothing better than sitting on one of the benches on the upper terrace while gazing at the infinity pool and listening to the sound of falling water.
author: Joanna T.

description:
I needed to grab a few things at Target and decided to stop by Yerba Buena Gardens. I got here on Tuesday, June 26th a little before 2:15pm.

I used to come here often when coworkers wanted to just sit on the grass and have lunch. We'd spend our whole lunch hour eating, talking, and soaking up the sun. There's a waterfall type installation to enjoy and views of the Marriott and St Patrick's Church. This day, I guess a festival was going on, so there was live music as well. I didn't actually spend much time here, but there was plenty of room on the grass to sit and chill.

Even though I don't normally hang out here anymore, it was fun revisiting an old spot. Nice place to just relax. Especially since it can be so chaotic walking around downtown.
author: Elena N.

description: They need security all over the children's play ground not just the adults area. Warning: If you see this kid around your children be careful!! He tries to lead toddlers and small children out of the playground out of sight from their parents.. this is a warning especially for parents who don't watch their children. Please be very vigilant!!! I posted pics so please if you see him be very careful and warm other parents.
author: Rita A.

description:
Love this place because it provides some greenery , peace, quiet for the craziness that is big city life. 

The MLK Memorial waterfall area in particular is very nice and I just like hearing the sounds of the water hit the pond.
author: Rod M.

description:
A gorgeous urban respite wedged in between the Metreon, YBCA, Moscone North, and Contemporary Jewish Museum with a good amount of open spaces to stroll, as well as an interesting array of elevated paths, viewpoints, and pedestrian bridges that connect the aforementioned adjoining buildings.

Of course, the real jewel is the water fountain that you can walk underneath. A true picture-perfect venue any time of the day, especially during the afternoon when the sun shines upon it, and just after dusk when the sky isn't yet dark, but the venue is all lit up. Whether you're here on a little break, or you're just cutting through between SoMa and FiDi, it's a welcome asset to the West Bay.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Yerba Buena was the name of San Francisco before the great city was called San Francisco. And no worries most Americans did not know that tidbit of California history. Heck, I'm a part-time historian & still forget! Yet, there's an urban park in the heart of San Francisco called...

Yerba Buena Gardens

It's a great little park found between 3rd & 4th Streets in SOMA. It covers over 2 blocks of urban landscape and includes a Martin Luther King Memorial located behind the largest man-made waterfall on the west-coast. The MLK memorial are large etched glass excerpts of his speeches that moved a nation. There's old school southern baptist inspiration in the overall design of the MLK memorial. See it! Other highlights include: 

An ice skating rink, a bowling alley, and a fully restored 1905 carousel originally located at Playland in the early part of the previous century. The Children's Creativity Museum (Zeum), a children's media and technology museum can also be accessed in the South block.

Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, a contemporary arts center can be found in the  North block. Eateries within the gardens include the B Restaurant and Grill & the Samovar Tea Lounge on the North block's terrace, Mo's Grill on the South block upper walkway, and a snack shop near the iconic carousel. 

Nearby attractions include: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Contemporary Jewish Museum, Museum of the African Diaspora, Children's Creativity Museum (mentioned above), and Cartoon Art Museum. The California Historical Society also has exhibits. The Metreon & theaters are located on the North block. 

Yerba Buena Gardens

I love this little oasis in the middle of a major city. It allows you to think or just zen. Read a book in peace. Just walk amongst the trees and kickoff your shoes on the green grass. I used to come here sometimes for a quiet lunch & just allow myself to take a step-back and not get so consumed with city living... and the best part... its free!
author: Eric R.

description:
Love the park at day and the water fall at nigh.. it's splendid!! Have been here on a couple of shoots too..

Definitely do go up the stairs to the rooftop of Moscone north.. there are a few restaurants and even if you are not hungry just sitting there on the stairs behind the artificial spring of the upper falls with a unique view of the city is worth it..

Convenient location too behind AMC Metreon 16 and next to super duper burger & Beard Papa's..!
author: Deebs M.

description: This is a block large Park in the middle of well close to the financial district San Francisco. It is a beautiful respite with the waterfall, a nice grassy area, and a wonderfulAsian-inspired fountain. It is right across Mission street from the Marriott Marquis Hotel in San Francisco. It's just a wonderful, relaxing spot.
author: Aleeta P.

description: I love city green spaces. This one is filled with a great combination of city streets and water falls. Great views of the surrounding city and many places to just sit and relax.  The trees are tall and mature, grass is soft, just a pretty place to be.
author: Brian M.

description: Beautiful park next to MOMA. Lots of fountains and flowers and open spaces.  We enjoyed playing Pokemon here.  There's tons of eateries nearby. I recommend grabbing takeout and eating in the park after a day in the museum. Enjoy the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial.  The whole park deserves some time to be relished even though it's less than a block.
author: Joy G.

description:
It's nice to have a green space in an urban, concrete jungle. I strolled through after dinner when dusk was setting in so I didn't get the full effect of activity / hustle and bustle, but it is a nice loop to walk.

Tip: go to the waterfall where you can walk behind/underneath it. There are quotes on the wall and a picture of MLK Jr. and it's cool.
author: Katie U.

description:
This place is wonderful and peaceful during the day. It'd be a great place to bring your lunch, sit on the grass, and enjoy your break. There's so many things to do in the area. There's a bar, restaurant, bowling alley, ice skating rink, museums.. it's overall a great place to go sight seeing or people watching. Maybe it was because I came here on a weekday, but there weren't many tourists here -- so I guess you can call this place one of those hidden gems that don't get too crowded in San Francisco with tourists. I'm pretty sure they'd be more towards the Pier or the Golden Gate Bridge. There's also lots of shade here to come relax, read a book, or risk out a nap session! 

4 stars because I was here with my boyfriend and we decided to play a game of chess on the boards that are offered for the public. However, there are some people here who basically watch your game and tell you how to play and what moves you should make and what you shouldn't do. So people can get pretty nosy with you and ask what you're doing when you just want to be left alone, so you can get some peaceful time here, but there are times you also can't. Just be watchful!
author: Mae-Elisa S.

description: Very nice and pretty place to just sit back and relax. It had a very nice view of some buildings with modern architecture, and the park itself has some nice fountains and such. Also kept pretty clean in my opinion which I love!
author: Christy L.

description: stunning green area in the midst of a concrete jungle. the metreon had a ton of food options which is conducive to a peaceful lunchtime picnic
author: Steph G.

description:
Yerba Buena, a thing of beauty!

On my last day in San Francisco, I finally had the opportunity to take a stroll through this drop-dead-sexy park. I made the most of my limited time here by gazing upon the park's most developed features. 

Things I took away right off the bat: Colorful flowers, touching monument to MLK, waterfalls, canopies, views of skyscrapers, and maintenance working on the job -- the most surprising, yet most refreshing component!

My advice? Take a minute to stop and smell the roses. Literally. No phones, no fuss. Just serenity and inner peace. Granted, snap some sweet pics, because the views are amazing! I'd kill to have this park in my backyard...3000 miles away...
author: Matthew C.

description:
The Yerba Buena Gardens are a wonderful green space right in the middle of downtown San Francisco. It's a great place to enjoy a siesta or to just sit around and talk to friends.

There's a nice small boardwalk and a tribute to Martin Luther King. There's also a good vibe overall, with people just hanging around doing nothing in the middle of a busy city. By the garden there's also a museum, a children's park and a few stores where you can get some coffee or ice cream. 

It's one of my favorite places in San Francisco. Nothing crazy special about it other than the fact that it's just a green field where you can lay down and enjoy the afternoon.
author: Steve N.

description: I love going here! It's so peaceful amidst the hustle and bustle of the busy city. It's right next to the Metreon across from St. Patrick's church. There's a nice waterfall you can walk under. I've been here years before for events and now I like to come whenever I'm in the city to get some fresh air! It's perfect if you're on a date! Go under the waterfall and kiss your boo LOL I'm definitely coming back here with my man HA HA He won't know what's coming for him!!!
author: Ramona G.

description: This is my go to spot in the city around the financial district/market area for a quick breath of "freshish" air in the city. Easy access to clean bathrooms in the matreon as well as picnic style food from the restaurant Lemonade nearby makes it a great break spot! Check out the MLK memorial fountain and the Shaking Man statue just up the stairs closest to metreon!
author: Justin S.

description:
Large green park in the financial district. A surprising number of homeless people, which is always wonderful to see. A great spot of greenery in the middle of the concrete jungle.

Surrounded by office buildings, a huge shopping mall and the Museum of Modern Art (which is temporarily closed), there is a huge fountain and lots of benches. Great for a lunch break!
author: Bruce K.

description:
Came to Yerba Buena on one of my final days at San Francisco. It's a small piece of greenery in the middle of a large city for people to be exposed to a bit if greenery and a wide open space for lunch.

There are a few benches placed around Yerba Buena and a mini waterfall. It doesn't seem to have an extravagent design, but just plain and simple.

It's pretty if you're the type of enjoy simplicity, but in my opinion, the design is a little mediocre and really artificial feeling. For someone who's a fan of nature and studies the environment, this may or may not be a place for you.
author: Kristy N.

description:
This little gem in the city is the perfect place to "get away" from the hustle and bustle of the city while maintaining your center location around pretty much everything. The waterfalls are soothing and the music on Thursdays is always a nice treat, I am actually here right now typing away and listening to the wonderful music playing by a band from Oakland (Country-Americana), the sun is out and the people have gathered here to provide eyes and ears on this sunny afternoon. Located walking distance from the Metreon and across the street from many museums and restaurants this is a great place to chill. They have Wi-Fi outside too! Sometimes I just like to find a spot under a tree connect to the internet and get some work done. 
 If you are looking for a great place to picnic in downtown on a weekday, let's say a picnic lunch while getting those 9 to 5 hours in I highly recommend the Yerba Buena Gardens. Here you will find locals, transplants, and tourist it is a good mix of everybody. Grab a snack inside the Metreon and walk outside to this well-kept garden in the middle of downtown.
author: Karlos G.

description:
This a great getaway for the kids in the middle of downtown. It is pretty protected from the winds and the sounds of the city. There are 2 big slides (I still haven't worked up the courage to go down the big one yet!), one smaller slide, a jungle gym, sand pit, soft ground (with curved edges for climbing), a small hedge maze (has seen better days) and some grassy area. There are also free toys that get brought out like hula hoops and balls.

I always like to come here and have a play/lunch date with the little one during the week. There are normally some chairs and a table free for lunch time and is fairly quiet, occasionally you will get a bunch of kids but there is more than enough room for everyone.

This playground is more suited for the bigger kids but the little ones still have plenty to do.
author: Tristan L.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is a beautiful park located in the Financial District/SOMA area. There are beautiful fountains which help create a peaceful environment in a hectic city. There is plenty of grass to sit and have a picnic or just to catch a few Z's. If you have forgotten a blanket have no fear as there are an abundance of benches. I'm so glad to have discovered this park.

2016 Review #28
author: Stephanie G.

description:
This is a really beautiful public space/Park. It is sad that it is NOT really a public space because of the over enforcement of ridiculous rules. A security person scolded my 14 year old son for going down a slide when he was peacefully playing with his younger siblings (ages 5-9). I asked her what the problem was when I saw this and she told me he was not allowed to play because he was older than 12. The rule is only 5-12 year olds can play. This is absolutely ridiculous to police kids trying to play outside and be kids in the fleeting years of childhood (trust me it's rare that the 14yo wants to play and slide) Kids are on electronic devices and playing video games enough. I was absolutely shocked to see a young teen SCOLDED for playing and running and sliding.
They quite literally have fun police at this park. How about we focus on real problems in the city and leave families playing together alone?
author: Dorothy T.

description:
This little oasis of green space, whimsical stone architecture, and sculpture installations is a welcome respite from the harsh grind and squalor of San Francisco's financial district.  

To wit, I had just found my way here after navigating crowded rush hour streets from the Powell BART stop, which is littered with homeless, disheveled, and forlorn human beings seeking warmth in the San Francisco chill.  I passed pathetic beggars at street corners who were being avoided by steel-faced, well-heeled financial and tech millioners making their way home from the sky scrapers.  The whole surreal tableau of American capitalism (or shall we just call it capitalistic feudalism) is disheartening.

Welcome, then, to the genteel atmosphere of the Yerba Buena Gardens, where those uncomfortable truths are suspended in the designed green space.  Transport yourself to calm tranquility in the meditative sound of rushing water from fountains. Check out the memorial dedicated to Martin Luther King.

This space is removed from the street through stairs, elevation, and sculptures which bound the street edges. So, remember not to just walk by, but take the time to walk inside the park and settle down for a break!

It's a lovely space made more seductive at night through the use of spot lighting, distance from the crowds, and the mega backdrop of the walls of sky scrapers humming with business.  The chess tables and picnic stops are well used. If I worked here, I would be hurrying down for a breath of fresh air! 

The church at one end of the square park makes the place seem friendlier and more human-scale.  You should also check out the Samovar Tea House on the upper terrace for a luxurious snack and drinks.
author: Prairie S.

description: Nice green patch in the middle of urban San Francisco. Very nice people around generally. Lots of things to do too.
author: Thaddeau E.

description: Two kids trying to kick a soccer ball, are considered a team sport and asked to stop. Stupid rule for a supposed family friendly area enforced by a rude security officer. Ridiculous.
author: Rosemary Q.

description:
This is a great park!   It is part of the convention center/Metreon complex.  it really is nice, it has water features, lawns, concerts and great views,  there are several levels and you never know whats around the corner.  I've been many times,  last visit i was re-routed for a concert and came around the corner to some beautiful red flowers...the free concert had good music also!

On nice days there are people enjoying the weather, eating food from Matron...  Its a great escape in a paved over part of town.  

Tip, the old church and MoMa are great views.
author: Mark B.

description:
2016 Yelp 100 Challenge Review #32

I was in town for a conference and made it around to this area.  Very nice.  It is designed for people to enjoy it.  Lots of sitting areas and foliage and walkways.  Lots of recycle/trash combos which I love but I think that is the city's ordinance.  It was a very clean park.  I did notice a few homeless people around (sleeping or what not) but San Francisco has a huge homeless/indigent population.  Overall, I thought this was a very nice, welcoming green space with a lot of dining options a stones throw away.
author: Steffanie B.

description:
A place to get away from the concrete jungle.

The first block between Howard and Mission Streets was first opened in 1993. The 2nd block between Howard and Folsom Streets was opened in 1998. The first block is just outside Metreon, and there's a large grassy area in the middle and a stage for events like the Filipino American Arts Exposition (or Pistahan) held every year. There's always a Filipino event every year, but I tend to favor this one because it's held here. Also, my cousin was the MC for the inaugural FAAE event a while back ago. I don't attend every year, but I do like going here because it's so convenient. 

The 2nd block is where they have the Children's Creativity Museum (ZEUM), an ice skating rink, bowling alley and a restored 1905 carousel that was originally from Playland-at-the-Beach in Sunset Beach. There are plenty of things to do and things to watch. Best part of all, you don't have to spend a dime to enjoy the place. 

Also on the first block is the where they have the waterfall dedicated to Martin Luther King Jr. St. Patrick Church and the Jewish Contemporary Museum is directly to the north and SOMA is to the east. There's not a single bad view from here and it is designed suitably as it uses its surroundings as the perfect backdrop. This is also a photographers' playground as every angle can be framed so beautifully. 

Since I work a couple of blocks from the area, I often go here to clear my mind, relax, unwind, de-stress or simply just to get away from everything and collect myself. It has a calming effect and I've used it to meditate on plenty of occasions. Recently, I came here on an early morning and watched a group of Chinese senior citizens conducting Tai Chi. I wanted so badly to join them, but I just ended up watching them and enjoying their movements. Watching them made me relax and lowered my blood pressure a bit. 

There are definitely plenty of benefits coming here, and you might discover something new every time.
author: John G.

description:
This was a nice place to visit, and it's really great that there's this sort of beautiful, natural haven nestled inside of SF. I can see why a lot of people might enjoy having their lunches out here on a nice day. I'd been walking around the SoMa area for several hours, so it was pretty nice to come to a quiet place and walk under the waterfall, as well as just sit still on the benches and relax. I kind of wish I'd come by when the Art Forum next to it was open, but I guess this means I should visit again at some point! :)

If needed, there's also free wifi and seating available in the forum next to the park, so that's nice too.
author: Diane J.

description:
Beautiful garden at the center of the big city! Whenever I have the conferences at Moscone Center, I visit here and take a short break. The grasses are well managed and very beautiful. The sound from the fountain makes me relieved from the busyness of daily life. I highly recommend you to grab some coffee and just sit down on a bench, or bring some sandwiches or anything with you and have lunch here on a sunny day. You can get almost anything at the and theater just next to this park.
San Francisco is a huge city but you could be relieved from it, and I believe this place will make your day happy.
author: May T.

description:
Great place to take a break from the buildings of the city and relax. There's a nice waterfall in the middle that soothes the mind from the hustle and bustle. You can either perch yourself on the green or walk up the stairs and sit on the benches. At the top of the stairs, there are two eateries which you can indulge in if hunger strikes. Also, it's right next to the theater and a small food court so either way so you have plenty of options to partake in.

Lovely place!
author: Shong H.

description: As for many others, this is for me an oasis in the middle of the financial district, a corner of peace where to have an impromptu picnic with colleagues, or just a place to go and hear some live music (concerts abound). Is so close to everything and the view of the catholic church is lovely. Just being there, smelling the grass while looking at the clouds is an enough reason to love Yerba Buena Gardens.
author: Carmen V.

description:
Beautiful garden tucked away behind the Metreon. A friend and I was exploring San Francisco and accidentally stumbled upon this gem when we decided to drink our bubble tea in the dining terrace in the back.

We first sensed the presence of this garden from the sound of water crashing onto the rocks from the waterfall. This waterfall was inspired by Martin Luther King, Jr. with his quotes on the walls. You can literally go inside the waterfall by following the path behind it.

Another option was to go up. Yes, there's a second floor! As you stroll up, there was a fainter waterfall that dripped on the walls. The median was beautifully decorated with pink-purpleish flowers.

At the top of the floor, you were first greeted by a quiet fountain that was the source of the water dripping below. You can see birds relaxing in the shallow water with the background of a beautiful church squeezed between elephantine skyscrapers that towered over it.

My friend and I had a mini photoshoot here and I would say that it was a success. This garden was definitely beautiful and I would love to come back here and show my friends. I now wonder how this looked like during nighttime...
author: Aj C.

description: Seriously have taken my dog here multiple times because it's somewhere that isn't filled with homeless people harassing me or my pup. I didn't realize dogs weren't allowed. Not only in the park through. When an employee asked if my dog was a service animal and I said no I walked to the sidewalk to find another 'dog park' listed on Yelp. As I'm writing this review another person told me only service animals and I need to step away from the park. What the fuck. I'm now on the sidewalk and I hear someone over his radio say 'no not even on the sidewalk.' Fuck you guys how the fuck is sf the most dog friendly city without being able to walk within 10 feet of Yerba buena. No buena. Bye.
author: Traci L.

description:
My son who is really big for his age loves to play with older kids. Last year, when he was almost 2.5 he came home with his head down because the older kids were mean to him and didn't want to play with him. My daughter and I always empower him and the next day he told DH, "dada, I'm ready to fight the bad boys."

When in SF, we are at this park everyday. Our boys need an outlet for their energy and their daily park time so they could take a nice nap :p

Besides the awesome, gigantic slides, the children here are diverse and play together  in harmony. An urban park at it's finest...
author: Christina W.

description: Middle of the city with kids the only place to be. Magnificent waterfalls and open lawns. Lots of history.  Unique treasure in the middle of the busiest part of the city.
author: Alex G.

description: It's a good area but the con is they're not dog friendly and this is the most dog-friendly city. Dogs are still always around and I pass by this area everyday with my dog and I'm not going to make my dog pee and shit on the streets and sidewalks if it wants to pee on a tree or corner of a grass area. Instead of yelling and chasing at dog owners, they really should enforce a small dog relief area at the steps of the sidewalk where there is grass. At least this solves the issue some dogs may go on the big area where people sit/lay down and allows people to take their dogs to a grass area where they can relieve themselves (no one sits on the grass by the steps anyway). And put actual SIGNS up so they don't need staff to constantly walk around chasing us down and giving us a bad vibe.
author: Jean W.

description: Nice place tucked in the hustle bustle of everything. Great place to relax and enjoy the beautiful weather !
author: Sheba A.

description:
In a forward thinking city the people that manage the park are not very forward thinking. Living two blocks from here, I walked my new dog through here many times before being stopped today and told they are not dog friendly. This is not posted anywhere on their website or anywhere near the park from what I've seen.

The rules are either not enforced by park staff, not understood or both because I was stopped once before and asked to walk around the children's discovery area because there was a show going on. I was not told however, ever, until today that my dog wasn't allowed (in 20+ trips).

To allow homeless people to essentially camp out here all day (which i'm in support of actually) but not to allow people to walk through with their dogs on a leash is absolutely ridiculous.

As I was leaving the park the security person was rushing over to tell someone else they could not ride/push their razor scooter through the park. What complete idiocy!

I hate to think that my tax dollars paid for this park I cannot walk through with my leashed dog or ride a scooter through and it's 2 blocks from my home. LOL!
author: Mike J.

description: I came across this hidden gem in the middle of SF while waiting for a table at Tropisueno, nearby. What caught my attention was the mini waterfall and architecture. It is a nice place to walk around and get so fresh air if you work nearby. This place also offers a cool view of a part of SF's skyline. There's an upstair part of this garden, too so just walk around and explore!
author: Minh-An C.

description: It's really nice to work so close to such a nice park.  I like to take my lunch here and eat.  In the summer, they have free concerts, which is nice.  There are plenty of places to sit and on any given day you will see kids playing on the grass, people doing yoga, or people eating on a blanket.  I've noticed security here is pretty on top of it and make sure to keep the homeless or suspicious looking people away.  It is also well maintained too.  Great little oasis amidst the high rises and chaos of the area.
author: Megan M.

description: I love this park. It's located near my office which makes it the perfect place to have lunch on a beautiful day with co-workers. You can brown bag it or stop by the number of places nearby for some eats. Find your favorite patch of grass and chow down. Make sure to dispose of all your trash when you're done please.
author: Scotty C.

description:
I'm happy to have found this place on Yelp and then saw it on a map and happily came here for a break from the crowded streets.  It's very easy to get to just off Market Street and also right beside Target.  The greenery in a busy downtown is perfect to relax and enjoy the grass or many seating areas.  

I like that they pathways weren't crowded on a weekday afternoon and there seemed to be a mix of tourists and locals, and old and young.  I came across the bowling alley and skating rink which I thought was pretty cool to have near the park.

The seating near the waterfalls is lovely to enjoy if the pigeons don't crowd you looking for a snack.  There's a tea place and restaurant that offers outdoor seating by the top of the falls and perfect relaxation spots.
author: Violet P.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! 

Whether you're here in the morning to jog around or simply sit to enjoy the peaceful ambiance, you can never go wrong by going here.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Great playground. One or two things for little ones but mostly age 3+ including huge slides and climbing structures. If you're bringing small kids, also bring a ball or bubbles 

Plus nearby ice skating where Boitano practices, bowling, grassy area for picnics or play near the MLK memorial, the Zeum, a carousel, and of course it's right next to a ton of food options at the Metreon. 

Really nice escape within the city. Check the calendar for special performances on the grassy area near the MLK memorial.
author: Marina N.

description: Gorgeous place to sit and people watch if you're in town. I was at the moscone for a multi-day conference and came here to spend time in between all the classes. The park is across from moma, next to the metreon (which offers a bunch of things to eat/drink), and has such a nice MLK waterfall memorial. Overall, it's a clean and peaceful little haven in the middle of fidi.
author: Michelle N.

description: We didn't spend too much time here but wanted to write that this is def a nice green space that is on a great area. I would def recommend others (tourists, locals,etc) to check this place out if you are looking to spend time out doors in this area.
author: Michael T.

description:
One of the reasons I love the bay and San Francisco so much is that there are so many beautiful parks and things to do outdoors. And the air just seems so much more clean and fresh there. My little brother took us here just to rest our feet before moving onto other things during our visit to the bay. Unfortunately when we were there, many buildings and attractions were closed (it was late when we went) but I could see someone easily spending a few hours here. 

The park is located amongst popular shopping centers and really big hotels. I'm sure you get all sorts of people in this park and it does scream PDA at some parts. There is a cute little tea shop on top of the waterfall at the park and there is even a view up there so it's definitely worth a visit just to gain some perspective on life and catch up with friends. 4/5
author: Michelle L.

description:
The perfect stretch of green to relax on when in the area touring the MOMA, Metreon, Westfield, Children's Creativity Museum, and other great museums surrounding it!

I love coming here and just sitting down for the tranquil atmosphere this garden exudes, allowing you to escape from the overwhelming bustle of the city just for a moment as you recharge under the sun on the hill, around the edge under the trees, or by the edge of the waterfall.

Definitely come by here when you're in the area and make sure to check out all the cool sculptures around it too, you can't miss em! Plus they have some free shows that happen on their stage from time to time, which just helps to provide an even more enjoyable vibe all around! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description:
I found this place based on the positive reviews from other Yelpers who have frequented this place.

This place is beautiful amid the chaos of the Financial District. It's such a stark contrast: you have tall buildings with hurrying people on cell phones and then you walk into this park area and all you can see and hear is the roaring sounds of a waterfall. It was beautiful and somehow poetic.

I love the words that lay behind the waterfall and it's worth ten to fifteen minutes of your time to read and grasp the meaning of them. I love the history it tells and the strength of man to rise and stand for something. 

Besides the waterfall, there is an open field for individuals to sit and relax from the hustle and bustle of life to just enjoy the moment. 

It's worth checking this one out.
author: M. J.

description: This was a nice open park area in downtown San Francisco. Complete with plenty of concrete and bench seating areas. A large grass field is the center of the area with a fountain style waterfall as the backdrop. Stop in to one of the surrounding shops and have a seat in the park.
author: Rawlins R.

description:
WOW!! (insert draw-dropping-I can't believe my eyes-are my eyes deceiving me-expression or look here).

Who would have thought in the middle of the metropolis that is San Francisco, that such a tranquil place of beauty could come to exist??!!  And yet....it truly does.

Welcome to Yerba Buena Gardens.

Yerba Buena Gardens is conveniently located across the street from the SF MOMA, and adjacent to the newly renovated Metreon.

My first impression of Yerba Buena Gardens was that it was just such a beautiful, beautiful place.  And a peaceful looking one as well.  There is a walkway that will take visitors across the rim of the park past trees, flowers, as well the MLK water monument and other water features.  

The main grassy area, or esplanade, is spacious and welcoming, and it is not uncommon to find groups of people talking amongst themselves, others reading a book, or basking in the sunlight.  People watchers will no doubt observe others having their lunch, individuals having a quiet moment to themselves, and families enjoying quality time together.

Residents and visitors will certainly enjoy this retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Bottom Line:  Gorgeous scenery.  Peaceful setting.  Surely I will be back.
author: Michael C.

description:
Beautiful park with sky scrapers of SF and construction crane as the backdrop.  The Yerba Buena Garden hosts summer music series/concert on the weekends.  Subscribe to there page to learn more.  Only caveat is paying for parking. We usually park on 5th/Mission and walk there. 

I did not see any homeless people around but definitely be cautious if you have little ones running around.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I stumbled across this place from a video on YouTube. Pictures and videos doesn't quite capture how unique this place is from all the other places in SF. This is definitely something different as it is located literally right in the middle of SOMA. The amount of stimulation from the views of the buildings, the different people, and sculptures is a lot but it's just enough distraction for a relaxing day. If you're hungry, you have a variety of places to choose from. There's target not too far. We came on a Sunday and managed to find parking but I can imagine it being a struggle to find parking but be patient. It's worth the visit. 

Get some boba, bring a blanket and pick a spot to take it in.
author: Danielle V.

description: Cool place to meet up with friends or a date.  Nice lawn area for a picnic if you work in the fidi. A lot of options for things to do near by, restaurants,  movie theater, and Target.  Really beautiful at night. Perfect for decompressing after work and spinning some poi.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
Truly one of my favorite places to meet up with people. I don't head to this area that often now, but when I do, I still feel very, very lucky to have this jewel of an urban park in our city.

Very conveniently located near public transit. Great spot for picnic-brown bag lunches. The music festivals are super fun. It's much better for meals now, with the re-do of the Metreon's food court, and I've also managed to get good work done waiting for friends at the tables on the terrace.

Years ago, I used to work a couple of blocks away in a job that nearly swallowed my soul. The MLK fountain saved my sanity: whenever things got rough, I'd literally take a walk. Coming to this spot, listening to the water, reading his words--it was a good place to let go of all the stress and to be reinsured by what we can each do, both individually and together.
author: Thy T.

description: Beautiful park. Came here with my friend after grabbing some lunch to sit out on the lawn and enjoy the scenery. The park is well taken care of landscaped. There is a nice waterfall/fountain which is pretty relaxing to be around, but there are a lot of people around this area. Plenty of places to sit under trees and canopy areas to hide from the sun. Plenty of museums around the park to visit as well. Definitely a nice play to just sit around and relax for a while. Clears the head, especially if you're on lunch break from work.
author: Steven P.

description: It's an oasis in the middle of busy SOMA and an easy getaway for a quick lunchtime retreat. Sprawl out on the grass, soak up some sun, listen to the white noise of chatter and the waterfall, and I promise you'll lose some of that stress work gave you. On a sunny day, the lawn is filled with circles of friends as well as solo cat nappers. With all the nearby lunch options, it's the perfect picnic spot. Check out the robust and diverse calendar of summertime performances on Thursdays and weekends.
author: Cristina S.

description: Some pleasant greenery in the midst of all the high-rises. Waterfalls and other public art pieces provide interest as you wander around.
author: Chance R.

description:
I was excited to walk to this area and get tea from one of the tea shops and hang out at this Park area.

Upon arrival I thought "man, this place is packed busy!" walked around and realized everyone there lounging on the grass and benches

were homeless :( spoiled my afternoon :( sad but also there was no place to just hang out as a girl with her tea
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
I'm very fortunate to have worked across the street from this serenity.  

On the days I'm stressed I would take my food out to the gardens and have a mini picnic.  It's a nice getaway from all of the people, traffic, and noise.  Best of all, there's live bands that play often so it's very relaxing.

If you're there, stop and check out the statues and art.  They are very unique and amazing.  

Public restrooms are provided.
author: Erica C.

description: Cool area with nice playground. Some construction in the area at the moment.
author: Anand R.

description: This was a nice park with a good view of San Fran. Strolled through here while at RSA and passed by this place to the Yerba Buena Art Museum. It's a really nice place to sit, have a picnic, or a good conversation.
author: Vikram V.

description: It's awesome to have such a clean and well-kept park in the city! During weekdays people come here to relax and grab lunch, and on weekends it's a great venue for events. Thank you Yerba Buena Garden! You are an oasis in this city!
author: Joseph L.

description:
A welcomed oasis within this fast-paced city...
Recognized as America's top 30 best urban park... A perfect place to play, dine, shop or just relax. 

We stumbled upon this park and decided to 'stop-smell-the-roses'...
Gorgeous, cool weather summoned others as well... 

I was astonished by the moving sculpture Urge... I was tricked into believing he moves to his own accord!  
(Shhh...there's a bench that faces the globe which activates when a person of at least 100 lbs sits or stands)
The elements of physical mirroring and mutual gazing between the Urge figure and its observer create a peculiar bond.  Very cool! 

Within walking distance to the Moscone Center, Contemporary Jewish Museum, Children's Creativity Museum, Garden Festivals...just to name a few.

A-must visit if you're in the area.
author: Snow W.

description: This park sucks. You can't even walk your dog around the sidewalk area surrounding the grass. There is a woman who works there that will chase you down and let you know. There are homeless people sleeping everywhere throughout the grassy area, often times with their ass crack hanging out. Takes the "buena" out of Yerba buena.. lol The upper level where the two restaurants are at is nicer and the flower garden is very pretty. For a better park experience go to Dolores Park. It's more spacious, beautiful, friendly, and you can bring your dog :))
author: Jeanette A.

description: Great place to hang out and chill. Kids tend to be in the area. Benches to sit on. Usually up kept very well so you don't wonder if you're sitting on a mysterious spot. Also there are random outlets in some of the benches.
author: Mimi T.

description: I cannot believe it has taken me this long to find this oasis.  Everywhere you turn there are people relaxing and something interesting to see.  What first caught my eye was the waterfall in the central circle; it was fascinating to walk behind, and was decorated with quotes of famous leaders of the civil rights movement.  On the opposite side is an aged cathedral bordered by modern high-rises, as well as the Meteron shopping mall, complete with numerous dining options and an AMC theater.  In the center was a little plaza, probably used for performances.  The park was very green and even though it's December there were still some beautiful flowers.  Great place to escape the bustle of Union Square and the shopping district.  I plan on visiting again.
author: Emily Y.

description: Always a great spot to lay out on the grass and enjoy a quick lunch break! The metreon is right there so I always grab boba from Sharetea and sit outside to people watch or simply enjoy the sun! Kid friendly, although you will regularly see homeless people sleeping in the gardens like wild pokemon. Not to worry though, they have security walking the premises all the time. Lemonade is right on the corner too! If you're looking for some expensive, healthy foods.
author: D. D.

description: Don't bring your dogs here. I was in town for a Tech conference and was staying at a dog friendly hotel nearby. This was the only park nearby and even my hotel advertised that I could bring my dogs here. After walking my dogs here half a dozen times, I was told today by security that only service dogs were allowed. I looked around and spotted a dozen of others dogs without service vests that were not being harassed. Yerba Buena Gardens seems to randomly enforce their rules. The park was also full of homeless people openly smoking drugs and Security didn't seem to mind. Maybe they just don't care for black people with dogs in their Gardens.
author: Johnny Y.

description:
Lovely respite of green in the middle of the masses of concrete and steel.  I am only docking a star because of all the fountains-  has someone informed the city that we are in the middle of an epic DROUGHT???  
Today, there is a lovely YB Gardens Festival featuring live music.  Perfect spot to enjoy my Mandalay Tea leaf salad from a nearby food truck.  At least 1000 people lounging in  the grass, plenty of shade trees and a wonderful breeze on this sunny cloudless day.  Also lots of wood benches and concrete ledges to perch on.  No lack of seating here.  Very well designed space - handi-accessible sloping walkways, rolling grassy knolls, and a small performance stage that benefits from the acoustics of the concrete surround.  Just steps away from SFMOMA and delicious restaurants and cafes.  Also borders on the Metreon- a giant food court plus AMC theater and Target. A block from Nordstrom and a couple blocks from Union Square and Powell St Bart station.  So convenient!
author: Christina R.

description: It's a little oasis in the middle of a city. It's very small, but unique. I love the architectural elements, the fountain, and the look of the surrounding high rises. It casts a nice reflection on the park in the late afternoon. There is a nice grassy area where you can spread a small blanket and have a picnic. I've been here just to relax or hear a concert. When it's nice outside, this place is PACKED. It's conveniently located to all the attractions on Market Street.
author: James W.

description:
~*~Entertaining Area.  Tourist Central.  Festivals during the holidays.  Carousel included~*~

I mostly come here because there is a Samovar tea house over looking downtown.

Lots of space, great for dogs.  

Skating rink
Carousel
Movie Theater
Pool Hall
Memorial

I missed stuff I'm sure.

Right next to/on top of Moscone Center.

Highly recommend.
author: Rimi K.

description: I've spent much time here over the years. Whether it's to just sit out in nature, people watch, an event, or even drunk wandering (read my SFMOMA review if you want to know more about that). A small carved out niche of SOMA that strangely separates you from the bustle of Mission and 3rd streets (see those during a rush hour!). One of my favorite views of the city are from upstairs looking over the MOMA or at the Cathedral across Mission. It certainly a spot for serenity
author: Kim N.

description: Nice place to visit and have some lunch here. Also, there are a security man to take care around. It makes me feel safe than other place.
author: Pinarat S.

description: Nice place to get fresh air and run around some grass. Beware though....plenty of pot smokers everywhere.
author: Mia D.

description: Absolutely gorgeous. I always forget that I'm in San Francisco whenever I'm chilling at Yerba Buena Gardens. This hub attracts such a variety of people. There are plenty of places to sit, read, chat, whatever you fancy. Everything is so colorful and cultural and it's especially beautiful on sunny San Francisco days. Even when it's packed, it's still super relaxing because I think most people come here to get away from the rush of the city. It's so peaceful.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
In a city with one of the lowest percentages of green space, Yerba Buena Gardens is a breath of fresh air. At lunchtime, it's super convenient to get take out from some restaurant in the Metreon (right next door), and enjoy it on the enormous lawn with your friends. Some parts are shaded and others are sunny, so everyone's happy! 

Or maybe you're crunching through a hard problem at work. Try taking a walk through the MLK Jr. memorial's waterfalls. Feel the need to read some inspirational stories? Do the same thing, except this time, slow down to read the plaques on the wall. 

Upstairs, a pool of tranquil water feeds the waterfalls. Birds like to splash around in the water. Watching them is calming, and it's kind of funny when they don't watch where they're going and get hit by a stream of water.
author: Kevin C.

description: It's an eclectic park. You can find the old and new within its vicinity , also the people chilling at the park, from high society to average and not so privileged . It's a safe park very open and lots of restaurant and appertifs place just walking distance .
author: Bu I.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is an integral part of the financial district. 

It's an area where children can play.

It's an area where people can take mid-day naps.

It's an area where bands perform.

It's an area where co-workers come to meet for afternoon meals.

It's an area where couples can relax in each others' embraces on the well manicured lawns.

It's an area where people go for that much needed Vitamin D fix.

It's an area where people hula-hoop.

It's an area where people flash-mob.

It's an area where people dance.

It's an area where people meditate.

Yerba Buena Gardens is a blessing in this fast paced world.

It's a reminder to slow down, to play, and to just be.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
REALLY like this park.

Reminiscent of Union Square because it's in the middle of Downtown SF but, it's an actually park with lots and lots of grass! lol

Great place to eat for lunch. But, ONLY if the sun is shining...or else you'll prolly be cold as eff!

Coming here on the sunny day I did made me feel super thankful to be in the Bay. Little things like that are kind of a big deal.
author: Laurie V.

description:
One of the few nice grassy parks in SF for relaxing and eating.  Features tables with chess boards, a waterfall you can walk under, without getting wet, and many neighboring food vendors.

On Thursdays, the Crocker Galleria (2 blocks away, near market & montgomery) has a large farmers market.  The close proximity makes lunching at the gardens with fresh farmers market fruit and veggies as easy as could be.
author: Wolfe S.

description: Come and escape life for a minute, rather if your on your Lunch break or just passing through. The park is so beautiful and peaceful on the right kind of day you sometimes forget your in downtown San Francisco. Great for all types of people.
author: Anthony J G.

description: This is a great park for photographers,  however there are some homeless people and drug addicts staying here. The only reason I gave it such a horrible review is because of the security officials hassling me for "looking too professional" with my tripod and camera. I take photos as a hobby, it isn't as if I'm selling the photos and I told them that, and they still hassled me and told me to fold up my tripod while some guy (who passed me like 2 minutes before) went behind the artificial waterfall was obviously smoking pot (I saw a blunt in his hand and smelled marijuana) and the security person didn't do anything at all. Didn't even go talk to him. If you security people is more concerned in getting a harmless photographer out of the park than the drug addicts then there is a big issue here.
author: Sunny W.

description:
This place is just as gorgeous in person as it is in pictures. It's a perfect place to relax and soak up the sun. I've read that this venue often features lunchtime concerts and other performances, but I wasn't lucky enough to catch any such entertainment during my visit.

Perhaps the most striking feature of the gardens is the Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial, which features a waterfall and a walkway inscribed with Dr. King's quotes and excerpts from his speeches.  

Without a doubt, Yerba Buena Gardens is the perfect destination for a tranquil afternoon.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Love this place. I take my dog here almost everyday.  Its so beautiful. They keep it clean so you dont have to worry about you or your dog stepping on a needle or something. 

They have an awesome grass area were you can chill and enjoy the waterfall and fountain. Love it here. I would recommend anyone to check it out.
author: B C.

description:
I reaaaaaaaaaaaaaally like this place!  I had NO idea a place like this existed!  Honestly, it's so much better than going to Union Square ALL THE TIME.  It gets boring after two trips. -___-  But walking around here and seeing children play around was awesome.  There is an ice skating rink here and it was cheaper and BIGGER than Union Square.  Jaaaank.  It was so much fun skating here!!!  They also have a bowling alley, but I heard it's really small (like 6 lanes or something).  But ice skating was $10 admission + $3 rental skates + $1 locker (for ADULTS)  Very good deal!  

It's a nice place to walk around.  You can go to the Yerba Buena Gardens above the Children's playground to walk around and enjoy the nice architecture buildings. :)
author: Jana L.

description: I really like this place. This is the first place to go when I visit San Francisco. Enjoy the afternoon and take a rest. There's safe and peaceful.
author: Ruby C.

description:
My favorite spot in San Francisco!! 
Beautiful objects are hidden here and there -EVERYWHERE! Yerba Buena is so beautiful, yet not at all intimidating.
author: Wendy G.

description:
Many days I walk through this park twice: once on the way to work from the Caltrain station and once on the way back. It's a great place to catch a break from the busy-ness of everyday life. Sometimes the gardens feature an art installation - I kind of miss the one with the huge solar-powered daisies.

When it's gorgeous out, we'll eat lunch in the grass or at one of the restaurants up top. I can't give it 5 stars because I always wonder to myself: How awesome would it be to get a game of ultimate going?
author: Wing Y.

description: What a nice place to spend the lunch time eating outdoors on a sunny day. Lots of greenery, plenty of space, great for people watching, and tons of food/drink options. Samovar just up the stairs is excellent :)
author: Joshua T.

description: This place has everything: ice rink, carousel, playgrounds, theater - great place to take your kids and let them run around
author: Tauasa T.

description: Yerba Buena Gardens is a beautiful place to take a walk on a nice day. It also serves as the perfect photoshoot backdrop for those who are looking for scenic places to shoot in San Francisco. You have your waterfall displays, your array of colorful flowers, your seagulls swimming in the water, your wooden benches to sit in and take in the view, etc. This garden is close to the Metreon food plaza and there are plenty of places to sit if you want to relax or enjoy your meal with a nice view. I absolutely had fun looking at all of the gorgeous architecture that made up this garden and would definitely recommend checking it out once if you haven't been here. This is definitely a tourist-y spot to take pictures at if you are in the Downtown San Francisco area.
author: Michelle S.

description:
YBG is a fresh spot of greenery in a field of office buildings, conventions, traffic and museums. Close to my office and lots of food for a quick lunch or coffee in the sun, and there's a free outdoor performance series in the summer/fall for added entertainment value. I can usually find a spot even on the most crowded days. The enormous MLK memorial fountain does a good job of drowning out street noise to give an aura of calm in the middle of the city. 

Grass can be damp, though, so I make sure to bring a jacket to sit on.
author: Krista L.

description:
Redevelopment.  It happens, for better or worse.  Long-timers miss the old places, newbies don't know that there were once old places here.  Anti-corporate types will gripe and protest, but you might as well accept that it'll happen.  So, ladies and gentlemen, let me introduce you to a redevelopment success story, Yerba Buena Gardens.

I'm not a long-timer.  But I read in one of Herb Caen's writings (on the other hand, if I actually know who Herb Caen is, that *would* make me a long-timer...) how this area was once Skid Row.  Then it all got razed, Skid Row moved to Sixth Street, and the Moscone Center was built.  It's a conference center built entirely underground, with a grand entrance on Howard but not much else.  The Moscone Center now takes up two entire blocks, all underground.  Aesthetically friendly, I suppose, but what do you do with all that open space on top?  The answer, as of the end of the twentieth century:  it was built up to become Yerba Buena Gardens.

I worked in the Financial District for several years, and love it.  One reason is that there's no shortage of places to grab your lunch and eat outside.  Still, San Francisco built one of the largest open space areas in this corner of the city, and it's a great add.  A huge lawn area.  Trees on the side near the Metreon.  A fountain monument to MLK.  A restaurant on top and a museum on the side.  A view of old - St. Patrick's Church - and new - the Jukebox Marriott - in the same glance.  And only a block south of Market Street!

What about the next block over?  The City decided to make this a family-friendly area.  Tall order in a city where the percentage of the population that is under 18 is probably half of other cities, and the idea of having a family is so Republican to many City dwellers.  But they did it, and now it's a great place to take kids.  The carousel, playground, ice rink, and creativity center make for a good excursion into the Big City if you live in the hinterlands.  Lots of places to eat in the immediate area.  Parking stinks, of course, but the 5th & Mission garage is a block away.

So there you have it, redevelopment done good.  Not a tourist destination, but a good place to relax.
author: Ron L.

description: The gardens is the SF hangout on a hot day.  Lazy days out there. Sunday it was nice out, park was crowded.  Fountains were flowing good.  Both restaurants were crowded.  Another good people watching spot.  Check out the old church across the street too. It's been there a long ass time.
author: Ron C.

description: Such a BEAUTIFUL place. Loving taking my dog there, it's just such a gorgeous, peaceful place. You're surrounded by happy people and beautiful scenery. They have chess boards which I think is awesome, I enjoy passing by the chess players. Everyone there is always in good spirits. Recommended!
author: R A.

description:
What a treat to be able to meet up with my 2 year old baby for lunch at the playground! Our nanny brought her out to meet with me and my husband. This is a great mid-point meeting place, because I work in the Union Sq. and my husband works in SOMA. 

We watched her run around, go on the slide and had lunch with her at one of several tables and chairs on the outskirts of the playground. 

The play structure is definitely for older kids, so our baby needed an adult to help her get up the step and come down the slide together. She seemed like the youngest kid there, but she still had a lot of fun. The playground is huge, so even with lots of big kids running around, there was plenty of room for our baby to have her own space.

The ground is so soft and squishy. It's fun just walking on it. The place being so close to the carousel is a huge plus. The overpass bridge connects the playground to the Yerba Buena Garden and Metreon where you can pick up lunch. 

We will be back for lunch date with our baby from time to time.
author: Su K.

description: Fabulous play circle/playground for my toddler. It's clean, fun and nice families play there.
author: Molly M.

description: My latest passion is walking and nothing is better than a walk in the park.  This park combines another of my passions, I absolutely love flowers and this park had a couple nice beds.  Also beautiful were the park's fountains and mural.  Wonderful place to relax.
author: Julie D.

description: I love this park because it's smack-dab in the middle of everything, and all the people there seem to actively enjoy being there. Who has time to drive out to the netherworlds of GG Park?
author: Lisa T.

description:
I dig walking through this lovely park. It's quite the respite from the financial district and probably one of the best places to stretch out, have a picnic, rest, breath a bit, enjoy the sunshine, etc in SoMa. I've sat many times here and had lunch and the walk through the park afterwards is always nice. It gives you a chance to get lost in the green space, waterfall, pretty stonework. 

Great spot. Enjoy it.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Nice little space in the middle of the city.

Only four stars because they need to do a better job at keeping thugs and bums out.
author: Morgan S.

description:
I love these gardens.  I used to work right next door many moons ago.  I love the scent of the freshly cut grass, the circular stage near the MOMA side of the garden, the assortment of flowers circling every entrance and exit, and of course, the amazing piece de resistance, the waterfall.  It's quite a tranquil place to just sit, reminisce, and reflect on what is important to you.  I happened to visit the garden recently and had the opportunity to ponder such thoughts as I heard the rush of the water splashing behind me in a calming state as the water crashed onto the edges of the MLK fountain.  I made a wish, I wish I'd been longing to make, and I hope, I pray, and I wish that it comes true sooner than later.

It's places like the garden where you can just stare at the surrounding area and realize that you're basically hidden in your own little world.  All around you are high rises, beautiful architectural pieces, in the middle of a business hub, but in this one square block, this little piece of greenery, you can settle into your own and let your thoughts escape you.  I've spent many times at these gardens, from festivals, concerts, in passing, and run to the mill errands.  But this recent night, was the best visit of all.  It made me think that life is about the moments you live, not the moments you lost.  A very beautiful, spirited person reminded me that night to just be happy, and my depression suddenly lifted off my shoulders; she was right.  People will always second guess who you are, what you are, the people you love, the people whom you associate with, and everything else.  It doesn't matter as long as you have love.  As long as you're true to yourself. I left the gardens a new man that night.  

You should feel free to come here, let your thoughts run wild, and take time to reflect on what's important to you.  Stare into the oculus of the MOMA, gaze into the clear skies, day or night, and marvel at what these gardens truly offer you, a place of peace, serenity, and natural beauty.
author: Myke Y.

description:
Like Lora M. wrote, "It may not be New York's Central Park," but it's a nice oasis in the middle of the City that provides a little something for everyone: gardens, public art, restaurants and food court, movie theater, ice skating rink and bowling center, carousel, art and technology kids museum, children's playground and interactive play features. 

YBG is also a block away from other museums like the Contemporary Jewish Museum and the Museum of the African Diaspora. The surrounding buildings house plenty of shopping -- there's even a Target -- and dining.

YBG is a public space, so you'll see/meet people from all walks of life. That's the beauty of San Francisco.
author: Claudine D.

description: a lovely oasis in the back of the Moscone center where kids can play and adults can relax or exercise
author: Maureen D.

description:
The playground with the awesome slides is closed for repairs, and if your 3 year old even does so much as look past the barricades at the construction, he will be swiftly disciplined by a park employee.  But it got worse-- same park employee me looked me in the eye and said, "you need to parent your child".  Dude, he's 3.  And you have no freaking idea what's it means to parent a child.  My kid was LOOKING at the construction, not even touching the barricade.  

We had just driven from Fairfield, ridden Bart to the city, and walked to the park with relatives that were visiting from out of state.  The whole trek took us hours.  So yeh, we chose this park so my kid (actually, all 4 of my kids, plus my niece & neph) could blow off some steam, explore, run around, and just be kids.  But from the minute we showed up, park staff was following the kids around telling them what they couldn't do.  And none of the kids were doing anything that could even remotely cause any harm to themselves or others.  Just being kids.  Outdoors.  At a PARK.

I tried my best not to let this experience ruin a beautiful day in the city.  Once we escaped the most stifling park ever, we actually had a really great day in SF.  The kids were awesome and everyone else we came in contact with was super nice and accommodating... I know, 4 siblings and 2 cousins under the age of 12 hanging out together in SF is a rare sighting!!!

Wanted to give rude & out-of-touch staff guy zero stars, but the park is pretty and urban and all the other kids and parents there were cool, so I give it 3.
author: Meg H.

description:
This park is one of the top reasons why I love San Francisco.  I've had some awesome memories in this place:  

Eating lunch on the stone chess tables with friends as we listened to a stranger read poetry

Grabbing a Beard Papa pastry puff from across the street and nibbling it as I wander through the hedge maze

Having a lazy Sunday morning drinking Blue Bottle and soaking up sun on the grass

People watching from the upper terrace

Hearing some talented musicians perform impromptu concerts in the middle of the lawn

Seeing families bring their children here and watching their eyes light up as they get a look at the majestic carousel

If I haven't already conveyed it, let me be clear: I LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: Christy L.

description:
The scene of one of those moments you just breathe in and appreciate life. While SF may be terribly prone to less than ideal west coast weather, on a gorgeous Friday, the sun came out and lit up the city and Yerba Buena is where people went to soak it all up, me included.

Sure, there was PDA galore, some interesting animated stories and dance moves, awkward passed out poses and the like, but there's nothing that compares to the feeling of leisure time. Power down the laptop, fold over the page in that book, turn off the TV and just sit. Sit and observe... whether it's simply 15 minutes or a half day, there's something to be said for being outside and doing absolutely nothing. Thanks YBG for reminding us all of that!
author: Katie B.

description: I love coming here for a little peace and greenery within the city. Conveniently located and close to restaurants and stores. Nice big lawn to stretch out on - I even see people sunbathing here in swimsuits. The noise from the waterfall is also very peaceful to listen to.
author: Bianca C.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is the name for two blocks of public parks located between Third and Fourth and Mission and Folsom Streets. A pedestrian bridge over Howard Street connects the two blocks, sitting on top of part of the Moscone Center Convention Center. Yerba Buena of course was the name of the town in the Mexican territory of Alta California that became the city of San Francisco.

Until he got too big, my favourite activity was to take the Kid to the big Playground. He would happily spend hours on the slide and other attractions while I comfortably sat off at the side watching him and catching up on my relaxing and reading. We would also go over to the nearby SF MOMA and look around. On the way, we would stop at the MLK Memorial (which is located behind a waterfall) and admire the etched glass excerpts from King's speeches (in multiple sister city languages). 

But wait there's more!

- On the terrace level above the waterfall is the pretty and scenic sister cities garden.

- The Zeum, an award winning children's media and technology museum.

- A restored 1905 carousel originally located at Playland-at-the-Beach.

- The ice skating rink and bowling alley.

- The Yerba Buena Center for the Arts and the nearby Contemporary Jewish Museum. Add the SF MOMA and you have a cultural Hat Trick.
author: Eric B.

description:
I was recently told by my doctor that I have a vitamin D deficiency, which is pretty pathetic considering I live in LA, one of the sunniest places in the US. Who knew that it took a work trip to SF, a far less sunny destination, to start working on my personal outdoor time?

After a cold, windy, sometimes rainy week, the sun finally came out last week in San Francisco and it was brilliant. I headed straight to this park across the street from my office with my laptop and every intention of doing work outside while I caught some rays. But once I plopped down on the clean, dry grass and looked around me to see other professionals, tourists, kids and dogs all relaxing and enjoying this rare summer day, it was nearly impossible to stay in the workaholic mindset. 

Considering that Yerba Buena Gardens are in the middle of SoMa, it's impressive that there is a relatively low number of crazies and harrassers... it's as if the whole city knows just to chill out and be normal and peaceful in this little urban oasis. The running water from the structure behind the grass lends some nice water noise, and there are a couple of outdoor restaurants just walking distance away if you'd rather be at a table enjoying a beverage or snack while getting that color. 

I feel really fortunate to have this spot of happiness for the rare occasions when it's nice enough to eat outside for lunch or even grab a whole afternoon and just lounge. Pure heaven!
author: Christina P.

description: After working and living in SoMa for a few months, the Yerba Buena gardens is a nice afternoon escape during a busy work day and is easy on the eyes with its burst of green in a city full of buildings. On a good sunny day, grab a nearby burger from Super Duper and chill out on the lawn! The fountains are also really nice and if you go upstairs you get a nice relaxing view of the skyline.
author: Sean S.

description:
The playground is located behind the carousel and next to the skating rink and Zeum Museum. A great space for kids to get their enery out and a place for parents to sit back and bask in the beautiful SF summer sun. I didn't know such a place can exist in the middle of an urban city. There are two main climbing structure with slides. I love that the entire playscape sits on recycled tires, which makes the ground super soft. No worries about head injuries here.

The playground could use some sprucing up, but overall it's a great place to take the kids. And the best part,  it's FREE!
author: alicia k.

description:
We come here when we meet halfway with friends between the Peninsula and East Bay. Great place for little kids. They have nice folks who come out and lend balls and hula hoops to share. The big slide is really fun. Probably best for older kids over 4, the little ones may end up getting squashed!

Bathrooms are further down by the bowling alley. Expect a long  line (or better yet, sneak in the bowling alley's bathroom).
author: Christine P.

description: Surrounded by the convention center, hotels, and businesses in SOMA, the Yerba Buena Gardens offers a great place to relax and enjoy some greenery. There's always people enjoying the sun, reading, or eating lunch. There's an an attached food court (in the Metreon), if you want to pick some take away lunch for yourself, or the excellent Samovar tea lounge up on the balcony. It can be busy at times, but the grassy area is big enough that you can always find a spot. There's also some public art scattered throughout (I love the running businessman), a memorial to Martin Luther King Jr, and a peaceful waterfall. It's a bit of an oasis.
author: Derek F.

description: After all the hustle and bustle enjoy a peaceful stroll around Yerba Buena Park...Good for the Soul anytime of the day :)
author: Merly I.

description:
Another nice park in the middle of a concrete jungle. As of this post, there's some construction nearby as Target prepares for their debut, but don't let that bother you when you're in the area for any reason. People usually come here with children, although adults sometime play here before or after movies, ice skating, or a meal as well.

On any given day, you have sunbathers, book readers, and a few vagrants since this is San Francisco and we're near Market Street. A large grass field is on the bottom floor, while there's a fountain with words of Martin Luther King, Jr. in the background. Restaurants and bars line the area along the top floor of this garden.

Overall, a great escape from the normal hustle and flow of being in downtown San Francisco.
author: Rob L.

description: You'll find me here for Alonzo King Ballets, totally a fan of the venue and performance.
author: Josie C.

description: This is a beautiful spot and an oasis in the middle of urban sprawl. There is a lovely lawn and the waterfall which you can walk behind which is amazing. Only 3 stars because there were lot of riff raff hanging around and smoking tobacco and weed. Ended up leaving quickly to get away.
author: Sunil R.

description: This is a great park in the city, which is nice to have amongst all the hustle and bustle that the city brings. I love to come here after going to church right across the street at St. Patrick's Cathedral to have a bite to eat, relax, reflect and people watch. Great spot if your alone, with someone, a group of friends or your family.
author: Clare C.

description:
Isn't it nice to have a place in San Francisco where you can picnic in the middle of your corporate workday?

Isn't it nice to just be in the sun?

Isn't it nice to close your eyes and hear the water crashing in the background from the water fountain?

Watch out for wet spots in the grass, they'll ruin your day.
author: Ben T.

description: This has been a great playground for my daughter since she could walk (~11 months). We used to go here every weekend. Recently, there is a staff person who is usually at the park and he is totally overzealous about the kids following the rules, which has lead to us having to leave with a crying kid several times. It's great that the slides are *supposed* to be for kids 5 and up, but my daughter was riding the medium size slide since she was 1 and younger kids can clearly handle it just fine. But now with the overzealous park cop always around, my daughter doesn't understand why she can't go on her favorite slide anymore. Two thumbs down for staff that ruined an otherwise great city park.
author: Richard M.

description: I like this place for the nice green grass field, big waterfall and Martin Luther King, Jr. commemoration, peaceful pond up above all flanked by the Metreon on one side, the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts on the other side and Samovar Tea and B Restaurant up on top.  A charming place to hang out on a sunny day (ignore the bums).  Love it.
author: Maile N.

description:
This place is so cool. I worked in the financial district for a year and never saw this place. 

You walk in this park and you are a little awe struck when I walked into this park. My husband and I went for a quick picnic here and it was amazing! (besides the guy feeding the birds and creating a full out bird army attack) We brought a blanket and some lunch and sat there and listened to the water features, watched the kids run and play, and just layed in the sun. 

The views of the church and all of the buildings just make it so beautiful (I am a true city girl) and it was so nice to be there and relax. There was not too many people there and so much lawn space. Great place to take kids and just relax with some food, drinks, and some good friends.
author: Lizzie D.

description:
It's time to get lost...
and, extend a zen moment...
to a nice mix of eateries, nature and post-modern facilities...
yep, you can find this in SF
author: Derek N.

description: This place is so filthy. They are people just sleeping on the ground and there is garbage everywhere, just disgusting. The people working there are also very rude. The fake "security guard" if you can even call him that, does nothing but harass people and make then not want to come there! I know you think you are important cause you are a big guy but you are just an a-hole!! Never go here unless you want to sit in piss and be harassed!
author: Jessica W.

description: Love this place. The sound of the water fountain, the tai chi in the morning, the music on occasion, food, mall, tea, view...
author: Thanh P.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is a tranquil oasis in the midst of the bustling city, a peaceful place to relax over lunch or with cocktails after work or on a break from the nearby Moscone Convention Center. 

The Gardens house an art complex, and a restaurant and tearoom (see my review for Samovar), as well as a soothing water feature surrounded by benches for lounging in the sun while enjoying the seagulls and ducks taking a dip in the waters. 

It's such a treat to come here to get away from the noise and hustle of the financial district, and would be a really nice place for a picnic on the verdant lawn. Just watch out for goose poop, mmkay?
author: Angela L.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is one of the most relaxing places in the area. It's quite big and easy to forget you're smack dab in the middle of downtown.

There is an awesome fountain and a large grassy area that make for a great picnic spot. (I try and have my lunch here at least 2 or 3 times a week because it's so peaceful)

One great aspect is that it's either not as heavy with tourists as union square or so big that you don't notice them.
author: André E.

description:
It's not as big as you would hope but it sure is pretty!  (Um, that's what she said??)

Yerba Buena Gardens really does sit plunk in the middle of the hustle and bustle of SoMa right outside a tea house and the brand new Target.  The grass is so green that I SWEAR they use green paint to paint it.  There are tinkling fountains that whisper Zen.  There are seagulls who bathe in the waters.  There is probably going to be at least one musical instrument of some sort being played by somebody.   If you are lucky enough to catch San Francisco having good weather you will enjoy Yerba Buena Gardens as a place to catch a break.
author: Heather F.

description:
Very cute little playground. Took my nephew here every day during our week long visit and he loved it. The sand garden/water feature is pretty neat but kinda grungy. There is a number of things for kiddos to climb on. My only qualm is that there is only one slide for children under four. The two big slides are for children 5+.

Should anyone come here my advice is make sure your kid is in clothes they can play in, bring some beach toys for the sand box and if you go around lunch time the yard is mobbed by day camps from the surrounding area.
author: Carly C.

description: Floor is a bit worn but kiddos don't care however the playground seems accident prone so keep a close eye on the little ones as they play and climb etc.
author: Joe B.

description:
