I discovered this place on my way to the Powell station one day after work, and am now happy to visit it any chance I get, whether taking a mid-afternoon walk; bringing my brown bag lunch; or just passing through whenever I am in the area. 

It's funny because with most places like these I always find a favorite spot. That's not the case with this one, though. I have sat at the cement chess-board tables on the far end. I have sat on a bench on the other end when you just get up the stairs. I have sat on the stairs by the fountains facing Third Street. I have sat even closer to the fountains, on the ledge. I have sat above the MLK Memorial, directly across the street from the huge church, and watched the people down below on the grass, and watched the birds take baths. I have even climbed up the really really high stairs -- you know the ones that have a sign up saying you are not supposed to -- and got some really wonderful pictures. 

The Verdict: City parks say a lot about a city's character, I think, and this one makes me love San Francisco. It just does.
author: Cara S.

description:
Whoever decided it was a good idea to put a park in the middle of the city was a smart person.

Yerba is a great place to escape your cubicle, eat your lunch, or grab an ice cream at Super Duper. 

The people watching is ON POINT. So many great things to watch, especially on convention days. The park is big enough to escape the shadows of the large nearby buildings and you can enjoy the foliage that the rest of the city lacks.
author: Katie K.

description: One of the best parks in the city. Security and cleaning staff should take more care of the park being clean and walkways not being a camping spot.
author: Antonio B.

description:
What a beautiful inner city garden/park!

Stumbled upon this nice and somewhat hidden little park while exploring the downtown area a few times this past month. It was a weekday when I was there last and there was a free jazz festival/concert going on. My husband and I had some free time so we grabbed a spot on the soft grass and listened to some music, it was great!

The sun shines into the park perfectly since no buildings really obstruct it, there are trees, birds, it's clean, well taken care of, and no sketchy people around so that was nice. If you need a break from the city and to enjoy some tranquility, this place is it! Stop by, have a picnic, relax, lay out in the sun! You can also bring your pets there I'm assuming since I saw plenty of people with dogs there.
author: Akvile D.

description: Beautiful park to lay down on the grass and stare at the sky. It's a bit hidden between buildings, but I think that adds to the beauty of it. There's a small waterfall and a cute little resturant on the higher level with a nice view.
author: Yasmeen H.

description:
I accidentally stumbled upon this park while exploring the market/Powell area; and I'm so so glad I did! 
Super gorgeous landscaping it's a little gem tucked away behind the bigger buildings so the tourists don't really venture here. 
There's a tea lounge up past the Martin Luther waterfall memorial and a big grassy area where you can find anybody from a couple of moms out roaming with their little ones to a hula hooping lady on a yoga mat. 
Perfect place to stop and enjoy some chocolates picked up from Chocolatier Blue just around the corner. 
There's also this dining commons there. Which is half my excitement about the gardens. 
Great variety of food. 
Great food. 
Great seating options.  
This is a big lunchtime attraction for the offices around the area so try to go before or after lunch rush. But I definitely suggest taking the time to explore this place! And just behind the tea lounge you'll find a bridge over the street that takes you to the bowling and ice skating area. Perfect photo op overlooking the Moscone Center
author: Morgan P.

description:
I never knew of this park until we went there and actually explored Yerba Buena Gardens.  Nice shops, children's museum, a toy store.... and this park... busy.

but huge slides, rubberized ground, climbing structures, water fountain... very cool.
author: Roger A.

description:
One of my favorite places to stroll when I'm downtown. It's an urban oasis, and a great place to have a picnic, lay in the grass, get some tea/coffee, and enjoy a tiny spot surrounded by architecture, and filled with flowers, and words of inspiration from Dr. King. 

It's also a great place for photo ops!
author: Lacey C.

description:
I work right by there.  It's a nice little oasis in the city.  Green grass and shade, with a little waterfall to add the ambiance.

Eliminate some of the sketchy people sleeping in the park, and it would be a dream.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Holy smokes, this park is SO BEAUTIFUL!  

We spent some time at the Museum of Modern Art and upon leaving, stumbled upon the Yerba Buena Gardens.  What a wonderful way to spend the day!  There's a gorgeous (I mean GORGEOUS) fountain and then just beyond, a beautiful grassy field for picnicking, frisbee, watching kids play tag, lazing in the sun, or any other activity that requires a solid stretch of soft, fluffy grass.  

Bring a pal or a good book or an appetite for some good alone time and some great people-watching, or just take a nice stroll through in the middle of your otherwise hectic day.  This park it truly an oasis in the middle of an otherwise busy and bustling city.
author: Kate H.

description:
This spot is very accessible to families and students who live in the city. I bring my students here every once in a while since it's very close to our school site.

Just recently I started to see Yerba Buena staff keeping an eye on the children's playground. This is really great because they provide hula hoops, bouncy balls, and sand toys for children who cannot play on the slides.

Thank you Abraham (the staffer that is usually present when we got to the playground) for making sure my students have a fun and safe place to play.

There are 2 giant slides, no children under 5 can go on them for safety reasons. There are smaller slides for the little ones though.

There is a small grass field for children to play in and also a maze made of bushes. 

However, there are only 2 restrooms that are near the children's museum.

You can also enjoy the carousel near 4th and Howard. Just be weary that this area is on top of the Moscone center that always has conventions. The park is not crowded, but getting there may take some time.

Until next time, have some fun in the sun!
author: Valerie A.

description: An amazing urban park  that offers winding paths, artwork, a waterfall, and flowers in a rather small area.  Even though the day I walked through was dreary and rainy, I enjoyed my brief stroll.  The waterfall was impressive - especially since you can walk behind it.  I'd like to come back during warmer weather to see the flowers in full bloom and the trees with all their leaves.
author: Andreas H.

description:
When I'm downtown and I need a moment of zen, Yerba Buena is my go to.  In fact, unless it's raining I'm usually picnicking here during my lunch hour with a Vietnamese sandwich from Latte Express or a salad from Grove and soak up some sunshine.  

Unlike Dolores Park, there are no drug dealers or drum circles to harsh your mellow.

Frequent performances and events on the weekends.  I heard a symphony of the Legend of Zelda (!!!) the other day.

It's patrolled by a security team, so no open containers or smoking on the grounds.

Plenty o' eye candy on warm days.

Enjoy while you can. I have a feeling it's going to be nuts once the Target opens in the Metreon this Fall.
author: Ryan P.

description: Scenic area with lots of places to sit if you'd like to get away from the hustle and bustle of the neighboring downtown area.  If you get something to go, it's a nice place to picnic and eat your lunch.
author: Karen W.

description: Right next to the Target and so great for a city escape.  Beautiful at dusk hours.  I really liked the MLK Jr civil rights memorial. It has quotes in lots of different languages. There is also a water station to refill your water bottle. It's such a garden oasis in the city!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Anyone who knows me knows I love parks. This place made me stop in my tracks and just...stop. I'd breezed past it several times before on my way going here and there. But, on the way to an important meeting™, I stopped. 

I stopped and took a moment to breathe, look around me and enjoy the beauty of being alive in a beautiful city and surrounded by beautiful things. I walked up walkways. I walked by waterways. I walked through flora of all sorts of shapes, sizes and colors. I walked under archways that transported me to far away places and let my mind wander to distant lands. I marveled at the quiet landscape that has, undoubtedly, sparked conversations, love and naughtiness. I touched the rock formations and wondered if man or nature had chiseled their magnificent looks. I sat and took a moment to relax, contemplate my luck to be right there, right then...and I took another moment to breathe.

I was late for my important meeting.™
author: Johnny T.

description: I work one block from the gardens. It's a complete oasis from Market Street. I love picking up food or brown bagging it farther in, past the stage & restaurants, there are benches under trees. It's a lunch haven for people who want to chill out, not hear traffic, people watch, without be harassed by crackheads.
author: B K.

description:
It was a wet, dreary day, but I finally got myself to Samovar for tea. I only stayed an hour and realized I was late, so I paid for the check and ran out, deciding north would be the best way to get back to my hotel. (Oh, these diagonal streets confuse me...)

But then I stopped and saw the beautiful gardens I had stumbled upon. It took me a bit to realize where I was and to remind myself that I was in San Francisco. The area is really modern and beautiful, with cherry blossoms trees; curving, checkered paths; and a rushing fountain. You can truly forget where you are here, and I imagine on an even nicer day, I would have enjoyed sitting outside longer and people watching. 

The park reminded me a bit of Millennium Park in Chicago, on a smaller scale.
author: Jess L.

description: Love it here. Wonderful place to spend a couple of hours. Vast green grass to lay out in, a cool tribute to Martin Luther King Jr., Samovar for your tea desires, and plenty of benches to sit around and enjoy good company. Being around all the abundant waterfall displays is truly something to admire.
author: Ann S.

description:
I love the park in Yerba Buena Gardens. It's the perfect spot to enjoy fresh air on a warm day. My coworkers and I like to go during spring and summer. It's located right by the metreon so it's really convenient for everyone to pick up whatever food they want before meeting on the grass. Chipotle, super duper, and la boulange are all great places to get take out. If you're looking for something a little nicer you can go to the rooftop area and eat at B Bar or Samavor Tea Lounge. Both are good and offer outdoor seating.

The park also features lots of free concerts and dance performances from May-Oct. Nearby there is also an ice skating rink, bowling alley, carousel, and children's museum.
author: Alice J.

description:
This park is beautiful (especially once the MLK memorial is done being renovated). It's one of my "special spots" with my partner. Great place to take a date on a stroll, or to relax to watch the buildings around you. Despite the history behind it (tearing down single occupancy rooms) in order to build the park, I think it's proven itself to be a very useful space for the city locals. 

Nearby places: the Metreon, Samovar Tea Lounge, SF MOMA, Jewish Contemporary Art Museum, La Boulange. 

Accessibility: close to the Montgomery BART station.
author: Emmanuel C.

description:
Come relax & enhance your cultural self at the lovely oasis that is Yerba Buena Gardens

We had just exited the Georgia O'Keefe / Ansel Adams exhibit at SFMOMA & here is YBG w/ all the welcoming tents & festivities.... we couldn't help ourselves but to go check it out

YBG is a small but awesomely landscaped park, adorned w/ tiny little flowering gardens; it also houses the Martin Luther King Jr Memorial  which is a MUST SEE in itself.  

Very humbling & amazing memorial behind the waterfall - stroll through while listening to snippets of his speeches & see famous quotes along the walls - supporting peace, love, & equality

Yesterday, we lucked into Pistahan which is there for this weekend only:
" The 16th annual Pistahan features seven interactive cultural pavilions and two stages highlighting music, dance, art, crafts, cuisine, artifacts, health and a trade expo featuring products unique to the Philippines: mother of pearl, bamboo, coconut, Philippine mahogany, pineapple fiber, Philippine pearls and more "

We found the setup to be mostly t-shirt stands & not so much the "crafts" they list above but if you like BBQ, this will be your nirvana - there are lots of stands....also the lovely dance interpretations on the stage in combo w/ the warm sunny day & it was an overall great afternoon at YBG
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Dash rocks this playground like only a 4 year old could. Big Slide and Bigger Slide are monumental, and then the Climbing Structure is an assured way to elude Daddy and disappear down the Secret Garden Path. 

Definitely a fun stomping ground, especially with Zeum and the Carousel right there. And a bowling alley and ice rink? Even better, keep an eye on their Children's Garden Series (http://www.ybgf.org/Programs/Childrens.php).
author: Nish N.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is a fantastic escape from the high rises of downtown San Francisco!  It's a close walk from both the FiDi and SOMA so it's easy to meet friends for lunch if they work anywhere downtown.  On a nice day you can find lots of people lounging, chatting and eating lunch.  

Perfect escape from work!
author: Liz H.

description: Great place to visit and take the kids for a day trip. If you love nature and the outdoors this is the place for you.
author: Dee R.

description: In the midst of downtown San Francisco and surrounded by high rises full of start-up dreams, it's a blessing to find a moment of peace and solitude in the Yerba Beuna Gardens. From the green grassy knolls, to the waterfall and newly blooming spring blossoms, this is a part of the Financial District that I relish. For lunch time picnics, morning retreat before the day starts or just to watch the diverse groups of people that pass through - there's something everyone can enjoy about this space.
author: Lani P.

description: A beautiful zen retreat in the Middle of San Francisco, with great restaurants and museums all around. Lunch here on a sunny day is bliss. A quiet break in the middle of a conference at Moscone is a treat. A great place for an outdoor business meeting.
author: Umair K.

description:
One of our new favorite playgrounds, especially Fridays in the summer when the Yerba Buena Garden Festival--Children's Garden Series holds kids shows (puppets, clowns, magic, acrobatics!) at 11am and 12:15pm. Great shows with good views and you can get soaking wet in the fountains in the playground afterward. I don't even try to keep my water-obsessed 22-month old out of the fountains or the wet sandy area because he has SO much fun. We just bring extra clothes and have to drag ourselves out of their at nap time. 

Only down sides for us are that it's a major summer camp destination and gets way overcrowded at times, and the metal slides get scorching hot on nice days. On the plus sides, the close-by bathrooms are clean and have a changing table, and there are lots of nice grassy spaces to hang out for lunch.
author: Gretchen T.

description: Not a lot of benches but plenty of grass. Lots of people seem to like sleeping/laying on the grass too. I saw some kids play around so it's probably relatively safe.
author: K G.

description:
It may not be New York's central park but it sure is a park centrally located in our beloved beautiful city of San Francisco!

After all the carb we ingested during lunch, we felt very sleepy and tired and thought of dozing off somewhere. I think we both already thought of this place while we were still in the restaurant. It's very close from the restaurant we were at and just walked to here. We fell asleep as we lay on it's green grass enjoying the sun. The nap made us feel better afterwards and continued to enjoy our day in the city.

It's a clean park and lots of restaurants nearby!
author: Lora M.

description: Awesome park to chillout, take a nap, people watch, or just zone out.  Beautiful waterfall that I love to sit in front of and just meditate to the sound of the crashing water and lose myself from the rest of the world and life.
author: Scottie P.

description:
Marry Poppin-esque. Worthy as being portrayed as a beautiful oil painting. 

Classy yet casual.

Trendy yet pure peacefulness.

Tranquility and just a top of the notch place to chill.

PERFECT for relaxing. Right in the middle of SOMA (South of Market)

I love coming here and reading a book!

Or join the locals and bring a brown baggie of some lunch or snack, and sunbathe or take a rest on the grass.

If you're Catholic, before or after you unwind, catch a mass across the street at St. Patrick's.

The park is conveniently located near all food places, museums and such. Yet, it is tucked away in it's own serenity.
author: Claire W.

description:
I can't imagine NOT giving yerba buena, or the other small handful of parks in SF that I frequent, five stars.

We live in a bit of a concrete jungle at times. So many people, not enough green down in SOMA. When I'm able to meet a friend for lunch at Yerba Buena, it reminds me that SF really is my ideal city. It's big enough that it's really no problem finding a place to sit and eat or talk, and it's full of other like-minded individuals taking a break from their busy days to find a little bit of peace.

This place is well maintained and not creepy or seedy. I tend to hang out in the area closer to third and mission. There's a bunch of food around there that you can grab and take into the park and eat there. highly recommended "place of zen" in SOMA. And also, it's a great meeting place for lunch if you work in SOMA/FiDi and a friend works in the other! it's really close to just about everyone.
author: Courtney A.

description:
What a beautiful park to take some time and to stop and smell the roses! As a visitor in San Francisco who is lucky enough to have this gem a few steps away from our HQ, I value this versatile green space very much. 
We ordered some carryout up the street and set up a little lunch time picnic to break up the workday and it literally left a smile on my face for the rest of the day. 

There was some musicians performing nearby and a ton of other like-minded people enjoying a breath of fresh air as an escape too. 
Although this park is located in the heart of SoMa, you get transported to another world. I. Love. It.
author: Marcia M.

description:
In the middle of the workday
I leave my windowless cube,
The screen deity which possesses my soul
Emerging from heavy doors,
My body begins to absorb the sunlight at once
Savoring it like a kiss.
Escaping the concrete jungle,
Up the pavement steps, across the pedestrian overpass,
Beneath the pool where seabirds splash, 
Lies a waterfall
An ocean of green
An urban oasis.
Hidden somewhere between commerce, art, church, and tea
I sit on a friendly bench and munch
Watching people, dogs, high heels, rags
I breathe in deeply, fresh air entering my mind,
And feel human again.
author: Kate V.

description: If you work downtown this is the perfect place to enjoy your lunch. Plenty of food options next door in the Metreon. The grass is always green!
author: Amy M.

description: Love eating and people watching on the green lawn with a waterfall in a background. I find this to be an effective way to unwind.  Taking a walk around, especially on a more grey day, is another good way to enjoy this oasis.
author: Olga M.

description:
Just when you think Downtown is only comprised of looming man made majesties, lo and behold, across Beard Papa, St. Patricks Cathedral and behind Metreon--fresh green grass, cherry blossoms blooming, exotic orchids and million dollar flowers, a waterfall commemorating Dr. Kings life and legacy, stone patios and stone benches, encircled by buildings is one of San Francisco's remaining "natural" (as close to natural a park here in the City can get, right) parks. 

I treaded across the green pastures and plopped down underneath a blooming cherry blossom tree by the butterfly sanctuary and studied for a few hours here. It gave me that "ah, simple moments" feeling and that fueled me to block out the kids playing nearby. I guess that is the only downer, it's a field trip site, which isn't a downer at all seeing as everybody has an iphone and headphones right :B

It's free of litter, very high security constantly circling the areas, I've smoked cigarettes there but not very many people do and I've seen security gaurds reprimand people for smoking and they're asked to either put it out or smoke in a designated smoking area. 

There's childrens playground across the bridge to Zeum , the carousel, the ice skating rink and bowling alley...and it's pretty nifty! The rubber floor is comforting, the slides are taller than any other local park and there is more to do, unfortunately the luxury of me playing at this playground is over as I'm twenty one and if you're 15 ++ they don't allow you to play there or even hang out around that area unless you have children! Best believe I will use my future child as a pass to get into this park and play! 

It's most fun at night but the park closes at 10! LAME.
author: Olivia Vanessa R.

description:
All of us are attracted to what we can't have.  I'm not thinking of a Romeo and Juliet scenario, but at a more local, innocuous level.

Last night I dreamt of eating eggplant skewers on a tropical Tahitian beach, with a huge pig roasting over the spit. In waking life I am allergic to eggplant, woke to rain pitter pattering on my window, with a cat jumping on my bosom, waking me up.

I began to ready for the day.  I envisioned myself in miu miu silver kitten heel sandals, with a short-sleeve cashmere dress by Alexander Wang.  For lunch I would have fro-yo from yoCup and sit in Yerba Buena Park and read for an hour.

Then a gust blew a tree branch into my window and snapped me out of my stupor.

I dressed warmly in sweater, pants, coat and boots.  I will not have fro-yo for lunch, I will have soup.  But I CANNOT forgo Yerba Buena Park.  Even in the rain, I find it very beautiful and enchanting.  It's definitely not an ode to natural living, but a sort of living testament that urbanity can have its own oases and sense of composure.  

Yerba Buena is a perfect for rendezvousing with a date or friend, and soaking in sun or soaking up rain 365 days a year.
author: Joanna M.

description:
A Great Park in the heart of downtown.  

The rubber floor mats need some love but the slides here are two stories high and the kids love um.  There's grass, sand and water to play in along with other play structures. The only concern here is that your kid wanders too far off. Plus theres good weather.
author: Joseph M.

description:
This is usually one of my favorite places to hang out at in downtown. However, with the construction of the Target and the construction of the upper level, it wasn't as nice as before. Hopefully after the construction is done, the place returns to normal.
It is one of those treasured spots in the City with sun and warmth throughout the year so there are lots of sunbathers, homeless included. Be forwarded. They are not intrusive but do smell so chose your sun spot carefully.
author: Wanlan X.

description: PLEASE keep the noise down on Annie Street Alley! People live right next to it and don't want to hear explicit music on high blast during the day when they want to relax at home!!!!!!!!!! This is ridiculous.
author: J L.

description: This week I've been walking around this garden for quite a few times because of the ACS conference. It's a very beautiful and relaxing park. I love the waterfall and the cool sculptures in the park. If I live or work around here, this would definitely be a great place for lunch.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens, you are a refreshing spot amid the bustling downtown scene. I recall a hot October afternoon, while trekking through the sultry streets and pavements of San Francisco. I found shelter in your park, away from the punishing heat and I noticed...

Reading
Sunbathing
Napping

Relaxation
Contemplation
Meditation

Chit-Chating
Consuming
Sight seeing

Trees
Gardens
Waterfalls

You are mini sanctuary and a huge treasure.
author: Sam T.

description: Beautiful!  We came here after visiting the Children's Museum.  We walked around, saw the statues, the landscape, enjoyed the view of the city.  It is relaxing, clean, and inviting.  I would love to come back here during a special event.
author: Trish S.

description:
Privately owned public spaces in the middle of the city. (swoon)

Yerba Buena Gardens is a beautiful space to enjoy your lunch, take in the sun, and kick back and enjoy being a city that's buzzing with life -- yet appreciates and values green spaces.

Water fountains and small sculptures and stages/venues for public concerts/lectures? Yes please. I think it's important to connect to the fact that we're human, and that we're not the center of the universe. Having a beautiful outdoor space available for anyone and everyone to utilize in the downtown San Fransisco area is a great way to remind us collectively that our busy lives and our busy days are just that... and that nature and the sun and the sky are bigger than we could ever be. Like Johnny T. said, what a gorgeous place to just breathe and exist.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Currently my fav spot to hang out with a book in SF. These gardens make for a pretty stroll or a quiet hang out if you catch just the right spot of sunshine or shade with a good book, or maybe your lunch.

Make sure you don't miss quotes posted on the walls behind the falls at the far end of the Gardens. Awesome!
author: Wendy P.

description: Ok this is a nice getaway from the hectic part of union square but it's no where near the 4.5 stars you people seem to give. It's just a couple of benches and faux waterfall. Christ, they have this everywhere.
author: M W.

description:
Where? What? When? Why don't I have any recollection of this place? I've lived and worked in Sf (at least one or the other, often both) for 1/3 of a century- my entire life, and I don't ever recall standing on Market, near 4th street and looking toward Mission St and seeing this amazing park. In fact had I not been looking for a patch of grass to treat Madison to a "romp"- I may of missed it yet again!

 Well, if like me, and you've had your head in the sand too, the next time you're shopping near Union Square on a lovely sun shiney day- stop by and check it out! It's a beautiful addition to the neighborhood (however long it's been there ;-)
author: Lisa H.

description:
Great place to take pics, or just sit on the grass read a book while having a snack.

Its a small oasis in an urban jungle, a good place to take a break from the day to day grind and just... relax for a moment.

The waterfall is very pretty during the day, but at night it literally has a glow

Its a good place to sit for a moment, and find refuge from the city life.
author: Aaron R.

description: Love spending days here. Always great people watching, except watch out for the many parents who ignore their children and let them annoy everyone by constantly chasing and yelling at the pidgins... I love kids but parents don't need to ignore them and let them ruin others experience in the park by letting them scream and run over where you are sitting.  Beautiful park though.
author: Lyndsey C.

description:
I don't think there's a static recipe for crafting the perfect fall afternoon.  I imagine that it changes from day to day, and that there are an infinite number of ways to end up with the desired result.  Here's just one.

-  Take one best friend you only get to see once every handful of months
-  Add one delicious dim sum lunch near the office
-  Fold in an Anchor Brewery Tour and
-  Toast well with unlimited beer tasting
-  Set out to cool on the lush grass of Yerba Buena Park
-  Fan gently with light autumn breezes under shady trees
-  Top off with cookie crusted Beard Papa cream puffs
-  And wrap with hugs, laughs, and a shared crossword puzzle

It looks like they were setting up for some kind of outdoor show while we wiled away the afternoon filling in our puzzle, but it wasn't terribly distracting.  The delicious eye candy ended up being a lot more disruptive, not that you'll hear complaints from me.

With the two of us, it really doesn't take much stay entertained.  But Yerba Buena Park provided the ideal foil to hang out, catch up, and still be conveniently located near the BART and my hotel.
author: Kevin L.

description: Got some rays on this winter day.  Great place to enjoy lunch outside.  Kids walking next to their strollers and running after pigeons and seagulls.  You've got the old church and MOMA watching you. You've got the old and the young.  Would Target change all that tranquility?
author: Helen L.

description: Great place to walk around, hang out, and enjoy fresh air.
author: S L.

description:
I go here a lot to decompress from work. It's only a few blocks away and you can sit in the sun and listen to the water falls in the background. So relaxing.

The only thing keeping me from giving a 5th star is all the homeless people who constantly are walking up to you asking for money, and the weird half naked people who feel like they need to show off their beer bellies to the rest of us. Really fat guy? No one wants to see that, seriously.

If you're stressed out, or just want a nice place to eat lunch outside, check out Yerba Buena Gardens. It's one of the nicer parks in SoMa!
author: Erik B.

description:
This spot is not only beautiful, but it's smack dab in the heart of SOMA, has free WiFi, and is perfect for a sunny day.

I was out and about this week and enjoyed sitting in the sunshine with my Toshiba, meeting new people, taking pictures, and writing.

Fun idea for the next nice day- play hookie, grab a blanket and a book, then see a movie at the Metreon!
author: Kristin F.

description: Take your kids to this little gem of a playground if you are anywhere near Union Square! It's the perfect place for them to burn off a ton of energy... slides, things to climb, even a water feature to cool down if it gets hot. We went to the Children's Creativity Museum right next door, you could totally make a day of it here in this area if you wanted to. Highly recommend.
author: Christine A.

description: Amazing little respite from the city where you can just lie in the grass and watch the blue clouds roll by!  There was also a free cultural performance by a local group, which adds to this park's charm.  And free of dog poop!
author: Vanitha S.

description:
Ahhhh, a little bit of solitude in SOMA. I love coming here with my lunch (usually a Chipotle burrito...can't get enough of those things) & soaking up some sun on my lunch hour. Somehow it is quiet enough to make you believe you are no longer in the city. Maybe it's the MLK Jr waterfall that drowns out the sounds of buses, cars, & motorcycles on Mission St. There is no shortage of places to sit, whether it be on a bench, a concrete slab by the fountain, or on the grass. Take your pick, there's plenty of room for everyone.  You may even catch a free concert if you're lucky.

The only thing I dislike is that they seem to over-water the lawn. It is ALWAYS damp or wet. So be sure to bring a blanket, coat, or lunch bag to sit on if you don't want brown stains on the back of your pants for the rest of the day. That could be awkward back at the office.
author: Erin S.

description:
It's not a coincidence that the days I spend relaxing in this park are the same days I feel like SF is the best city in the world.  Such a little gem in the heart of downtown.  Who wouldn't feel like they're in a dreamland when you're surrounded by greenery, skyscrapers, kids running around blowing bubbles and a waterfall? True story.

Beautiful, well kept landscaping in a part of the city that gets loads of sunshine.  And if you hit up this park in the summer, you're likely to have free entertainment as part of the Yerba Buena Festival series.  I've caught mime troupes, orchestras, Asian doo-wop and even a circus here.
author: Natasha W.

description: Randomly happened upon the a 12 piece Cuban jazz orchestra on a beautiful day. It was the Yerba Buena music fest. Great music, ambiance and organization!
author: Jess G.

description: Really nice place to go take a nap during a sunny day. If you decide to have a couple of drinks, make sure the cops aren't around. They tend to get pissed off if you don't offer any to them.
author: Nestor C.

description:
While this funky little playground looks very space-age and futuristic at first glance, it also made me think of the playgrounds of my youth when we played on equipment coated in lead based paint.  Metal monkey bars and tube slides are the anchors of this fun hot spot.  My kids had a blast running around the play circle, dangling from the bars and shooting out of the slides. 

NOTE:  The tall tube slides are slick and your kids will slide out fast!  Encourage riders to stick to a feet first position to protect their heads.  My seven-year-old shot out of the slide like a cannon ball, had she come out any direction but feet first I'm pretty convinced we would have had to make a trip to the ER.
author: Kristine D.

description: Best part of staying in this area for five days was being able to walk through these gardens anytime. Beautiful, clean, refreshing.
author: Marina S.

description:
What a great SF scenic gem of glory. It's one of my favorite places to bring lunch to during work with a big group. Relaxing waterfalls overlooking the city with well-kept grass.

It's also a great people-watching park, you get everything from musicians, to young professionals, to the occasional crazy person. The only downside to this park is that it can sometimes be soggy due to the morning fog, that said I'm always up for a trip to the park.
author: Jason M.

description:
This park is one of the best things about Soma. I mean we are surrounded by a bunch of corporate buildings and bam there is this nice little park with great views of the city surrounding it. You can see lots of people enjoying lunch, a small concert or just reading a book. I see a lot of dogs in here too. There are some sculptures and artificial waterfalls and just some nice sights.

Overall on a nice day this is still a chill place to be.
author: Greg G.

description:
Beautiful playground.   My kids loved it, but I thought it was a little crowded.  Clean and well maintained.   Something for kids of all ages.  

Since I'm not from this part of town, I paid $18 for parking so my kids could play here.
author: J Y.

description:
An oasis in the otherwise grimy SOMA district and definitely a good lunch break option for those nearby.  Surprisingly clean and well maintained by dozens of tax-funded city workers.  

Can't fairly give it five stars, however, as it's not in the same league as the area's true outdoor gems like Golden Gate Park, Tilden or the beaches.
author: Geoff D.

description: After a few hectic days in SF (conferences and lots of exploring), I just wanted to chill out in a park and decompress. It was a really nice sunny day and Yerba Buena totally fit the bill. I sat behind the waterfall and it was so peaceful and relaxing. I just sat and read and could've stayed for hours, but the sun was migrating and my sunny spot became less so (which made me chilly), so I got back to the rest of my wandering around town.
author: Renee E.

description:
Often held up as an example of great urban planning, this children's playground is a big hit for kids and parents alike who live in the area.  Rizwan and Khadija had a blast playing with a wide diversity of kids.  There is an area where kids can splash in water, a massive sandbox, a climbing structure but the major attraction is the two tall slides.  The highest one spooked Rizwan for quite a bit, but when I finally went up there with him, he went down and had a blast.  Needless to say, he rode it multiple times after that!  I took Khadija down it a couple of times, and boy is it fast!!

I took a star off because it could take advantage of the space, by adding some more items.
author: Iftikhar K.

description:
This place is great: nice open space, green grass, cool water feature, great views, it has it all! It's also super close to the metreon, so grab your lunch and have a picnic here on a nice day.

The space also hosts events that are open to the public, which are most often shorter concerts during the lunch hour.
author: Emily V.

description: San Fran is a great city to see al sorts of things.  This place was cool.  Bowling alley and ice skates?  CRAZY!  Bring your kids!
author: Dean P.

description: Really nice park. It's great to have green space downtown (and close to work) to hang out, eat lunch, or just walk around.
author: Sam W.

description:
The Yerba Buena Gardens are the epitome of entertainment and relaxation.

Not only is there a big field with no garbage at all, but they frequently have small concerts or performances.  Being near the South of Market area, there are also a lot of Filipino-American-themed events taking place at or near the gardens, including the Pistahan festival held every summer.

It's also put in quite a convenient area.  The Gardens are just a walk away from The Metreon, various hotspots to eat and lounge such as a Starbucks, YoCup, and Beard Papas--not to mention the huge shopping area just around the block.

The gardens are also home to the MLK fountain, which houses his "I Have a Dream" speech in multiple languages, including Tagalog.  This is pretty amazing because it shows that was a true step forward for not only the Civil Rights of African-Americans, but everyone in this world.

With the current situation we live in now, it's important to look at our roots, and why we've gotten to where we are, and there's no better place to gather these thoughts than the Yerba Buena Gardens.  Whether you're looking for a good time or just want to settle down, this is the place to be.
author: Danreb V.

description:
This is the SOMA's shining jewel and one of my favorite spots to spend a beautiful day (especially in the summertime when the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival is in full swing).  Breathtaking vantage points that mix old structures with new, landforms both organic and geometric.

Being a privately-owned public space, they're very particular about what you can and cannot do in this park (they've got eyes and ears scouring the premises at all times).  So sadly that means no dogs allowed, but on the bright side of things: no dog shit!
author: Andrea U.

description:
I really like the shaking man.  And I really, really love the waterfall that goes over the area with MLK quotes.  It's a very emotional experience.  Also the quotes are in different languages, which is great for tourists.  Also I can practice my foreign languages.

Great park,  They have cool events here.  I like the sidewalk chalk drawing event they had.  In the middle of museumes, food and movies.  I love this spot.  One of my personal sweet spots.  I like to drink a cup of coffee, take some pictures and smoke a cigarette here and just kick it.  

When I am here I think of Barry McGee's show at Yerba Buena, the times I spent here with my friends.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Beautiful spot by the Metreon in SF. Lovely fountain, great landscape views. People watch, relax, chill on the green grassy area in front of the fountain, or have some way overpriced tea at the tea lounge above the fountain.
author: Esther Y.

description: Great place for city kids to play, enjoy the grassy lawn area, play structure, bowling alley, indoor ice rink and just run around and be a kid. It's well kept, clean and safe.
author: Holla F.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens must be the best public park in the downtown area of SF. I love simply walking through it on my way somewhere, which generally provides me with a new source of enjoyment each time. Whether it is the people enjoying some (rare) SF sunny weather, a free concert in progress or being set up, or the occasional nude roller skater who I've seen there. 
The park itself is surrounded by some of the best hotels, museums and shopping in the city. You have the SFMOMA right across the street, the great bar at the St. Regis as well, and then the Metreon right there in the park. The options are endless. If you haven't checked out this park, definitely plan to spend some free time there.
author: Scott C.

description: How have I not been here before...such a lovely park in the middle of the cement forest. A friend and I went to Samovar, a lovely tea house. I ordered the Quinoa Waffles, super tasty! If I'm in the area I will be back!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Great place to have lunch on a sunny weekday. We usually make a pitstop at whole foods and bring it over to sit on the grass. It gets a bit busy between 12-2 with others  doing the same, but there is always tons of space to pop a squat :)

FYI- Not ideal for sunbathing in a bikini, napping or relaxing.
author: Seema M.

description:
Love this place!  I walk by here once a week to go to my volunteer commitment, and have been through here plenty of other times on various midday jaunts when my destination was MOMA or the Metreon for a movie.  It's a really lovely spot of green and bubbling water, so plenty to look at whether you like watching nature (okay, plants and birds, it's not exactly a forest), watching people, watching traffic, building-gazing, sky-gazing, cloud watching.

Also love that there's lots of places to grab a snack or a meal and come here to eat.  Plenty of trash and recycling bins and actually probably one of the least littered green spaces I can think of.
author: Amanda P.

description: This spot is a great spot to relax during the middle of the day if you work or go to school nearby.  The waterfall drowns out the nearby traffic and the park is big enough where you can find a spot to sit down and relax, and just get away from it all.  The cherry blossoms were beautiful and the next time I'm here I'm going to make it a point to really check out some more that this complex in general has to offer.
author: Mel G.

description: One of my favorite spots!  The MLK cave walk is touching and heartening.  It feels great to connect.  San Francisco on a beautiful day is epic.  And Yerba Buena is a great spot between cafes and museums.  Try the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts on North side of the square, the museum has phenomenally creative and awestoking exhibits.  Also South West corner of the plaza is the good version on the bakery chain which originates here in SF.  Be aware that the main plaza is not dog friendly and on the weekends they can be tough on it.  Cross Mission street and dogs are allowed.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Beautiful place to take a stroll.  

Been here a few times now, but only after living in the City for YEARS and having no idea that it even existed.

Justin L. and I like to walk through Yerba Buena Gardens either before or after a movie at the Metreon.

A great little breath of fresh air right in the heart of the City.
author: Chelsea C.

description: What an oasis in the middle of the city. I was lucky enough to stumble on a free concert by the Marcus Shelby Orchestra. Absolutely great music. What a well done event. The event was paid for by the YBG. What a cool city to spend money on the arts. Lovely.
author: Katie J.

description: My new fave place. The nice MLK waterfalls. The LaBoulange newly opened. The rolling grassy fields. The view of the church across. The tea place Samovar to enjoy on a pleasant Sunday afternoon. Central and next to Target, Metreon Movies Theater...and a bunch of other things nearby. The bowling, skating, and playground is on the other side.
author: Angela L.

description:
This is a great little playground. Big slides, water play, and a climbing area. The spongy ground cover is great for the safety as falls are inevitable.
I suppose it's nice that there's usually someone on duty, but they gave me a hard time about letting my 2-year-old onto the slides, even with him in my lap. Considering he can do 50-foot slides alone at a farmer's market, I think he can handle these 15 to 20-footers.
None-the-less, my son had a lot of fun playing here one night while Mom got her hair done and we killed time waiting to go to to eat.
The playground itself is not real large, but there's lots more to explore at Yerba Buena.
author: Brian T.

description: Took my 2 kids here 4 and 6. The park itself is just a green area. The ground was hard grass/dirt with divets of mud everywhere. There was some live music going on which was nice but very little vegetation or flowers. The waterfall was cool. We also crossed the street and visited the play structure which was fun for the kids. I just expected way more space and green grass, the pictures depicted it as a lot bigger and greener and just the name itself lent itself to wide open spaces of green grass and flowers. Yes, I realize this is in the middle of a metropolitan city I was just expecting a "Central Park" type of experience.
author: Joy G.

description:
YBG exhibits traits that describe the woman of my dreams:

- Sunny and vibrant
- Has a nice view
- A tranquil place from the hustle and bustle
- Often poignant but still fun
- Frequent ball juggling

...what?
author: Keane L.

description: The playground recently got a facelift and it looks much better! All the rubberized flooring, which was tattered and worn, has been replaced. And they added some climbing handholds and footholds to the hills near the big slides, so kids are clambering up and down there a lot more (and more easily) than before. A nice incremental improvement to an already great park, featuring the best giant slide in San Francisco, hands down.
author: Ian K.

description: go to the second floor and you can gaze the metropolitan and feel the modern tranquility! I love watching the waterfall and seeing the skyscrapers. There's the museum, cafe, tea house, merrygoround, theater, etc etc. things to do. This was where I had my first date with my lovie!
author: Iris Y.

description:
The nice things about this park is the thought that went into the planning: there are nice little nooks and areas you can wander around in, as well as a big open to the sun area. I like that.

The waterfall/fountain is nice. On a warm spring afternoon this place is a great spot to lounge with a book and listen to the water cascade down. It doesn't hurt that there's some thoughtfulness behind the fountain. Go check out what I mean.
author: Wes T.

description: People watching: excellent! Seating availability: good except when there is a conference going on.
author: Paul H.

description: OMG! Mini picture taking is NOT ALLOWED, especially if you are using with ONLY TRIPOD! What's wrong with tripod?
author: Calvin Nicholei L.

description:
Me: Wait so this playground is free?

Random Parent: Yes, isn't it great!

Me:  Are you sure?  Those are pretty amazing slides there, plus the sand castle pit and enormous climbing structure all on this super cool and soft faux gravel top...there has to be some sort of admission right?

Random Parent: Yeah no, its just a great park!

Me:  Really because the ice skating rink charges admission even when you aren't skating...and in my opinion this is like the best playground ever...maybe they make you pay at the front?

Random Parent: Um no, its free.  Its really free, it is.

Me:  I mean look at how clean everything is here, its really clean.  Its not like this is a public park....don't you think they have to charge something to maintain it...it doesn't make sense.  

Random Parent: Would it make you feel better to give me some money because seriously like, I don't know how else to tell you other than IT IS FREE! (storms off to the other side of the park)

In conclusion:  An amazing playground that appealed to my two year old as well as my pre-teenager and her best friend.  Its clean and safe and located in walking distance to the Westfield Shopping Center enabling your kids to wear themselves out here so they sleep in their stroller while you shop at Bloomies for hours and hours undisturbed.
author: Rosie C.

description: Recently rennovated - - in beautiful condition and lots of fun - slides very high and perhaps scary & dangerous for little guys
author: A. C.

description: Great place to relax over your lunch break in the city. I come at least once a week, but I still find that I'm discovering new hidden gems. They just opened the area up top by Samovar with a bunch of benches overlooking the fountain, and there are a ton of small tables and stone benches all around. Keep an eye on your belongings though - twice I've seen people run through and steal phones from people that are just laying around and not paying attention to their surroundings.
author: Lauren D.

description: Gorgeous waterfall memorial, expansive sunny patio, trees, birds, not exactly what I was expecting to find next door to a Westfield mall yet there it is! This is a great location to bring kids or have a summer time picnic. Its surrounded by great activities such as bowling, ice skating, a merry-go-round, shopping mall, and museums. Yerba Buena is a perfect little oasis in the middle of an exciting area. Admittedly it does occasionally have the odor of some of it's more colorful inhabitants but overall what a great place!
author: Kari G.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in the area. It's a good place to bring a lunch and relax when the sun's out. The white noise from the MLK memorial helps to mask the surrounding sounds. Although, the traffic on Mission along the north side of the park never seems to be very busy.

The area above the park where Samovar is located I also a great spot to catch some sun, bite to eat, drink what have you.
author: ryan c.

description: YBG...is an oasis from the hustle and bustle of the Moscone center. The park features the MLK waterfall, gardens, an open paddock for laying out and catching some rays. The close proximity to museums and the movies make it an ideal place to have picnic lunch. Great for all ages. Clean and convenient.
author: Sergio F.

description: We were at the gardens during an all out dance party....it was great.  People were dancing in tango lines, children doing arts and craft, and the band rocking all day.  Check out their community/family free events...it's great for all ages.  Pack a picnic and enjoy the gardens.
author: Ally W.

description:
Great place to eat lunch on a nice warm sunny day. Avoid the areas by the southwest side they are super wet after the sprinklers or something, either way muddy. The steps are nice place if you all want to sit without having to worry about your but being wet. 

I wish it had a bit more shade on those really hot days when everyone is going for the shade.
author: Rohan D.

description:
This park lets you escape the city while still being in the city. San Francisco being the concrete jungle that it is (especially downtown/SOMA), it's amazing to find a patch of green grass & trees blooming red & yellow flowers in the center of it all. There's plenty of places to chill-from the wooden benches to the concrete seating in front of the water fall to the numerous rock formations dotting the park. 

The BFF & I took up residence on one of the concrete seating areas for a quick lunch of salad, quinoa bowl & smoothies while enjoying shade from yesterday's warm, sunny day. There were plenty of sun worshippers, people watchers & friends enjoying their healthy summer lunches, like us. The park was a clean, quiet, serene space for us to pass the time before our movie started.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Very nice & the grass is well taken care of.  Its a nice size garden/park.. Worth hanging out there.
author: Jocelyn C.

description: The Jewish Museum, SF Moma, Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, Samovar Tea Lounge, an expansive lawn for lounging, Metreon Mega Movie Complex - a lot you can do with an afternoon at the Gardens. Check it out...
author: Denise N.

description:
What I like most about this place is that even though a band is not always playing, there always seems to be someone dancing or singing to their own music. 

An urban oasis. 

Make sure to read the MLK quotes under the waterfall.
author: Helen K.

description: Yerba Buena Gardens is urban planning at its best. It's a small urban park, tucked between the Metreon shopping mall, the Museum of Modern Art and the Moscone Convention Center. The park features redwood and oak amongst the trees, a beautiful lawn for sunning, benches to sit and read, but the star of the park is the memorial to Martin Luther King Jr. It is a dignified remembrance of a great man. After visiting that, be sure to head upstairs atop the waterfall for quieter view of the park. Stroll across the bridge and ride a 19th century carousel. The park is great for kids too!
author: Lefty R.

description: Great place to relax on a nice day!  Beautiful view!
author: Stacy S.

description:
I brought the kids (ages 1.25 and 5) here three times in three days.  It just keeps delivering.  The playground is really unusual and interesting.  It has a giant slide.   We played in the fountain and looked at the seagulls.  We went bowling.   We rode the carousel many times. We looked at the marble maze.  We hung out on the grass. We admired the flowers.

We didn't make it to the Zeum or the Zeum store.  Or the ice rink.  Or the tea lounge.  Yet.  YB Gardens appears to be an inexhaustible fountain of delights.
author: Sudo N.

description: Nice and peaceful park. I like the waterfall and memorial behind it they have dedicated to MLK.  You see people just lounging and relaxing out in the open.
author: Sandy N.

description: Nice for taking a stroll around.  They've a grassy area where you can picnic or just nap or whathaveyou.  There's a cool water feature as well.  Sometimes you'll find a hot dog vendor in the area as well.  Yerba Buena Center has varied performances but I haven't physically seen any of them.  Previously they've held Apple Product Announcements and the Star Wars tours.
author: Wyman L.

description: This park has some of the best scenery, and people watching. A great spot to eat your lunch during the work week, grab some sun rays, and enjoy a little piece of relaxation in the midst of all the hustle and bustle. I don't come here often enough!
author: Ashley D.

description: Beautiful park and tons of really pretty flowers.  It's a nice little oasis in the hectic section of downtown(ish).  Wish I had an excuse to come down more often.
author: Robin L.

description: Great outdoor setting for lunch and relaxation. I love the free concerts they have during the summer!
author: Bridget B.

description: Very friendly place for kids in a pleasant environment. A lovely park on top of a building. I would never have known this was here.
author: Adam F.

description:
Nestled atop the Moscone center, outside of the Ice Rink, this is a cool outdoor playground for your kids, complete with that smooshy mat stuff so they don't get hurt when they fall. 

Do not come here after midnight and attempt to re-live your youth by climbing on the jungle gym and sliding down the slides. A security guard at least 10 years younger than you will ask you to leave, even if you are sober.
author: Drue C.

description:
Small, but warm and sunny.  I used to regret walking by on our laps up Nob Hill, as the bands were playing in the sunshine.  Today I went to meet some Yelpers for lunch, and the bandstand was quiet.  Without a thousand people on the grass, the green looks a little small.  But the park goes beyond that.  Above the waterfall is another plaza, and the waterfall itself is fed by an infinity pool.  The sunlight on the concrete made the park warmer than the 59 degrees of the surrounding neighborhood.  No walkway is straight for more than 100 feet; the outdoor labyrinth effect adds to the park's apparent size.  

It feels different out there than it looks from inside the Metreon.  I'm glad I went out to feel the space first-hand!
author: David D.

description:
They don't allow dogs, not even if you're just walking through and promise to carry him and keep him of the grass.
What a fucking joke, a beautiful park in the middle of down town San Francisco and they don't allow dogs. And they're real Nazis about it, too.
Yes, the park is beautiful, ladida. But what good is it to me if I can't enjoy it with my favorite park mate. It might as well not exist. I want my tax money back.
author: Carla P.

description:
Yerba Buena Gardens is a park I pass every morning .

It's really serene at 8am and I really love the waterfall.

The plants and flowers are always going to put a smile on my funny face at 8am.

It's an amazing and lovely garden to walk through so early everyday.

I'll love it forever. Especially when it's really sunny in July and Hot...mmm
author: Katherine N.

description:
The place has a nice, modern, "sanctuary" feel to it in the middle of the downtown area. One wouldn't expect gardens/a small park nestled among all the tall office buildings in the area, but here it is: Yerba Buena Gardens.

I have to admit, I hadn't been back to Yerba Buena since late May 2008; on Tuesday, I went there to meet up with Kate V. for brown bag lunch. I forget about Yerba Buena being so close to work, and it is one of the best "outdoor" spots downtown. 

The place is small, but large enough for people to lounge in the sun on an unseasonably warm/nice January day. I'll definitely choose coming here over Union Square because...there's actually grass here, and not as many homeless (if any?) milling around (as opposed to Union Square).
author: Helene K.

description: A good spot to take a break from downtown without leaving-- with plenty of grass and places to sit and the occasional free concert.
author: Rose M.

description:
Ah, my first foray into drinking in a public area. 

Unfortunately, the law prohibits underage kids from brownbagging it in a popular downtown SF garden in the middle of the day. The cop was cool, though-- just came over and told us no drinking and asked us to get rid of our stuff and walked away. No carding, no standing around to see if we got rid of our drinks, nada. So my friend and I dumped our drinks b/c we're good girls, but we had fun just the same. 

Besides the cool cops, the Yerba Buena gardens are just a nice place to hang out and people watch. My fav has always been the MLK Jr. Memorial fountain. I make it a point to go through there everytime I'm at the gardens.

If you give this review a "useful" vote, you're crazy. ;)
author: Merrill H.

description:
In the midst of the downtown hub, many (including myself) forget this lovely mid block green patch of love.  I have passed by, sat in, listened to a concert or two, and ate lunch and snacks more times than on my fingers and toes (that's 20).  It piqued my early interest in landscape design and thoughtfully embraced and paid homage to its initial surroundings, including the big church along Mission and SF Moma.  

This past December I trekked through this garden with some family and noticed some very cool colors of red, blue and later yellow and happily returned a few days later to snap a few shots.

My favorite part:  the large expanse of green and full grown redwoods.  My least favorite: the fountain-while a grand gesture, the execution is messy as it continues to falter and age ungracefully.

More green to come.
author: Jen L.

description:
Beautiful space in downtown to relax during lunch. I'll often get food inside the Metreon and come outside here to eat in the sun. It's beautiful at night, too, when the water features are lit up and the nearby skyscrapers glow.

I'm especially a fan since the sun and warmth have returned. The people-watching is great now that bust is springing--er, now that spring is busting out all over. The park is popular among lunchers, sunbathers, and tourists alike. It's also a popular venue for music festivals at the small concrete stage. Watch for weekly offerings during the summer.

Trivia: Appropriate to San Francisco, "Yerba Buena" is a sprawling, mat-forming perennial whose name translates as "good herb". It is also the name of our fair city before it was seized by the U.S. government in 1846 during the Mexican-American war and renamed San Francisco (after the nearby mission).
author: Bill B.

description:
Of all the great spots near my office, this is hands down my favorite. 

What is it about some grass, a few trees and the sound of falling water that manages to just *reset* body & mind?
author: Stephanie P.

description:
If you live in SF, you know it's rare to live near, enjoy, or spend time in a degenerate-free park. While most other parks in our fair city are littered with bottles, syringes, and street-dwellers of all varieties (drunk, high, panhandling, peeing, or-if you're lucky-sleeping), YB is a beautiful oasis in the middle of hustling, bustling downtown San Francisco. 

Living across from Yerba Buena Park comes with some major perks:
-walking across the Yerba Buena overpass on my way to work in the morning is an excellent way to start the day
-easy access to the carousel (yes, I do love riding fake horses to creepy circus music. I also enjoy strawberry milkshakes and My Little Ponies).
-lounging in the park on sunny days 
-the list is endless, really

Throw in all the events, the Zeum (I will borrow people's children for an excuse to go here and play dress-up, make music videos, play with clay, and participate in the light-square game), the awesome bowl-shaped playground and monster slide and sandbox (you have to have a child with you- again, I will borrow a child to gain access to this exclusive club), the waterfalls, and the location and we've got one hell of an experience on our hands.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Really pretty place and perfect to have a picnic on a nice day as a change of pace from the mall food court across the street or any of the overpriced cafe/restaurants in the area.
My only complaint: weird hobos diving in the fountain of the MLK memorial looking for change.
author: J A M.

description:
I ate my lunch here - it was good.

I worked on my tan here - it was good.

I read my book here - it was good.

I observed all the pretty ladies in their business suits and summer dresses - it was great.

I forget I am in S.F. when I am here - that is priceless.
author: E E.

description: Been coming here since it's established. A rejuvenating place in the heart of downtown sf. One of the places you must visit if you're ever in town.
author: Chase L.

description:
The latest trend for city parks, community spaces and museums is to create an integrated environment that uses the urban setting as a part of the overall experience.  As a model for urban redevelopment, Yerba Buena Gardens is a crown jewel.  It is a fantastic example of how a park space can be created within a busy downtown area.  The water, the museums, even the Metreon (with its outside stairs and patios) contributes to this garden for a modern city.  

I love the waterfall with its evocations of Martin Luther King Jr., the carousel where even adults can be kids again, the lovely Center for the Arts --- all the pieces come together and mingle effortlessly with the diversity of people and the background noise from busy San Francisco streets.  Without that background, the pulse of the city, this park would lose some of its vitality and vision.  I go to Golden Gate for the transcendental experience of leaving the city for a while.  I come to Yerba Buena to participate in the life of my adopted city.
author: Suzanne B.

description: Omar Sosa and his band were amazing! Perfect weather for an outdoor show... More to come every Sundays. Get out and catch a show...it's free!!
author: Sofie Z.

description: I remember when they were building this place. The pictures of what was being built were so futuristic, I didn't know what to expect. The land is nestled between really busy streets and the park area is located close to the streets. You wouldn't think you can find any peace and quiet here, but you can. The waterfall of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial washes out most of the street noise. This is an oasis in a near true sense of the word. Modern buildings (and one old church) surround the grassy park area, but you're still able to find peace. Free music events are held weekly during the summer and other events are held throughout the year. There's a lot of focus on promoting and funding the arts. The downtown area desperately needed a space like this. I love it for what it is, for where it is, but it doesn't rank high as far as places to take my out-of-town friends...unless we were just looking for a place to take a break from the shopping.
author: Helen L.

description:
I hate to be a downer, but this is the truth. I was here yesterday on 8/19, and there were a few problems: the grassy circle was full of pigeons, pigeon doodoo, litter, and bottle caps; there was way too much rubble and trash on the playground; and the water play areas were not very clean. 

Now, I fully believe in exposing little ones, including mine, to different environments to challenge their immune system, but putting my toddler on the pigeon poop on the grass was too much for me. The whole area should have been cleaner. I also didn't appreciate the litter left behind by stupid parents who were too busy eating and drinking. 

What could have been a totally sublime five-star experience for us was marred by the refuse. I'm really hoping that the grounds management team can do a little better.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Beautiful place with pretty blooming trees, nifty waterworks, and cute statues. Yerba Buena is nestled amongst shopping centers and huge hotels, so it is quite a busy place--not too ideal for complete peace and quiet. It is, however, definitely a delightful place to visit. Check out my pictures :)
author: K W.

description:
Yerba Buena is a the perfect place to:

Lay out and soak in the sun
Lose yourself with a good book
Take a nap
People watch
Draw so you are not considered a creep for people watching

Oh so peaceful. 

Minus one star for the giant seagull stalking around and attacking my food.That's right, a SEAGULL. If I wanted a giant seagull to harass me I would've gone to the beach.
author: MJ T.

description: I want to live out of a tent on the lawns of Yerba Buena Gardens. I wish to fall asleep to the soothing sounds of the waterfall, bask in the sun with a good read, and practice my tango under the pale moon light. YBG is one of my favorite places south of Market in San Francisco. This is one of the Cityt's best place to enjoy a quick picnic before attending MoMa.
author: Michael G.

description: Been to quite a few free events here (shows, short concerts, plays). It's a nice spot in downtown. I particularly like getting tea at samovar on a nice day; it's great for people watching on a weekend...or a slow work day ;).
author: Erika C.

description:
Every since summer started, I come to this park at least once a week.  I am a Preschool Teacher for a Child Development Center in SoMA so we walk the kids to the playground often.  

A big climbing structure, a pole, one mini-slippery slide, 2 tunnel slides, and soft rubber floor to run around in... the kids love it :-)!  

With older children playing rambunctiously (climbing up the slides, not watching out for younger kids when running, swinging from the trees, and cursing), it's nice when a Park Guide is present at the Play Circle.  Abraham and Patrick (the current Park Guides), are very good about making sure the playground is safe for everybody, especially the little ones (my little ones).  

Yerba Buena has so much to offer.  Don't forget to stop by the garden area, go through the maze, check out the bowling alley and skating rink, and even be a kid again on the carousel.  All summer, every Thursday starting at 12:30p, there's a Music Festival that I take my kids to in the grassy area beside Metreon.  

It really is a perfect "fun" place and I'm glad that the preschool center is only a few blocks away :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Oh Yerba Buena let me count the ways I love you.  You are clean, you are flat, you are hilly, you have legitimate grass, you have a waterfall, your seagulls are more passive than aggressive.  You have flowers, you have steps, you have walking paths.  You have a plethora of eating establishments nearby.  

You are across the street from my office.  You are so great that I do not need to use my skillz to convince friends in the financial district to come visit me there for lunch.  Again, you are across the street from my office.  You are SOMA's lightly manicured garden; a true "living" room that just feels good much like your stain-free, seams intact, most favoritest t shirt...and we all know how hard those are to come by.  The photos speak for themselves.  Muah.
author: Jenn T.

description:
This is perhaps the BEST children's playground anywhere.  There aren't that many things to do in the play area itself compared to some playgrounds, but all my kids really want to do is climb up the big slide and slide on down.  The adults just scout out a good place to sit in the shade and watch from afar.  They work off some of their excess energy and the adults get to relax and have a nice conversation.  Other things are the xylophones, the water feature.  Once when we were here, the ranger came out with a parachute to do parachute play.

After the slides, which we always need to pry them away from with a count down -- "OK three more slides down, now two, now last one," we sometimes go to the carousel and then it's back to BART and home to the East Bay.  

Yeah, to my kids, BART is part of the adventure.
author: Patty W.

description: love the place, love the spring/summer festival....we are lucky to have such a beautiful garden in the city....remember when it first opened...the trees were so small....now it's gorgeous and so many people get to enjoy it...
author: Maria E. M.

description:
Been here before but a long time ago. . .

Just strolled through the garden this past weekend and was reminded what a beautiful oasis it is.  A great place to sit with a friend and catch up, chill on your own, or bring someone special for a picnic on the grass.  The Samovar Tea Lounge gives a nice urban zen vibe to the park.  The infinity waterfall adds a tranquil hum.  

I'll definitely be back soon to spend more time. . .
author: James M.

description:
Good place to be relax except birds.. 
the picture is still on my cellphone and I am missing all the buildings,  
church, SF MOMA, and Metreon etc.., around it 
one of most beautiful park in SanFran. 
lovely picnic place for brunch and lunch with friends..
chatting, playing ball, and sleeping in sunny day.. Zzzzzzzz...
author: Julie K.

description:
Very urban, but what do you expect from a park build in downtown Frisco.  My 16 month old twins enjoyed the single dowble wide slide.  But they were limited to what they could do.  I like the location and the lil ones attempted some of the other play structures, but it only worried me.  The park is definitely for the 4 year olds and older.   I will take them back at when they reach that age.. 

The Kids Museum next door call ZEUM was pretty cool, the lil ones enjoyed the cushioned building block areas and the green screen area with the slide.  But again they were limited due to there age and skill levels.

The energy in both places were good and there were many families out enjoying the day.
author: S H.

description:
I think "gardens" is an apt description for this place, rather than "park".  It doesn't strike me as a frisbee-throwing, sunbathing sort of spot so much as a little oasis of tranquility amidst the downtown bustle.  Plus, you're literally surrounded by cool stuff: YBCA, Samovar, the fabulously incongruous St Patrick's Church, the Metreon (ok, so that last one's not all that cool).  I actually like the gardens best right after sunset, when the lights of the skyscrapers beckon you oh-so-classily towards the endless riches of the San Francisco night while you draw in one last breath of waterfall Zen.  

Speaking of the waterfall, did you know that there's an MLK memorial behind it?  Just noticed that for the first time last weekend.
author: Wes M.

description:
I'm in love with this place...i love it day or night, it's beautiful any day and time. Somehow i can always find a quiet place where i can relax even during the busy lunch time! When the sun is shining this is the ultimate lunch place...if you prefer to eat outside. 

I also bring my guests from out of town here especially at night and they love the views!
author: Katja S.

description:
Like a hidden oasis in a vast desert.

I like the open green spaces here in where events are thrown sometimes. It is just right next to Metreon and across Yerba Buena center but this park has a unique atmosphere. I like how tall buildings surround this one block watching the waterfall and the old cathedral (St. Patrick's Catholic Church) right across the block. This is truly a place if you want to get away for a short time, have a quick picnic, stroll the breeze, or enjoy the sights! Not to mention there's a random carousel and the kids playground across the bridge. Whatever the case this area is a breeding ground for your refreshment!
author: Brandon H.

description:
Across from the office, this little park has became my refuge before, after and even during work. It for me is home to many a conversation as its green grass and architecture many times have invited, even magnetically pulled me back in.

As one will experience many employees from the area are enjoyed here(I would estimate a six or seven block radius) catered by take out from a variety of local businesses - and as we consume within, appropriately disposing of the waste afterwards, the sunshine graces us and smiles not many of us leave without. 

The park is well groomed by the gardeners and has security in the form of some sort of officer, an officer that isn't very serious but does in fact do the job as a deterrent as the job of an officer should. He wears a hat that I think I could get from a vintage shop in the haight, but then again, perhaps the guy has some style. I'll talk to him tomorrow and found out. The water in the park gives it something special, whether perhaps it is me experiencing some sort of childhood nostalgia, either way during the day, or during the water-lit night, its something very unique to the city. 

In YBG, you will always find a friendly atmosphere, a spot for great conversation and release from work for a moment either via the falls, waterside to enjoying a mid-afternoon nap either on one of the many benches or within the grass. 

Its a good one, the best one, and i'm sure you'll see me there.
author: Travis W.

description:
I thought I had hit the jack pot when I realized that this park was so close to my hotel and I realized I would have a place to walk my dog. However, I got yelled at by some women with a walkie talkie telling me there were no dogs aloud in the park. 

Are you kidding me, come on SF, take whatever you are paying the
crazy women with the walkie talkie and invest in some doggy poo bags, then everyone will be happy!
author: Alicia K.

description: Very hard to beat for well located scenery.  It's a nice place to bring a bag lunch, and it's near a lot of entertainment and shopping options, but you can't hang out here because of its downtown-ness.
author: Luke M.

description:
I got chased by the little black birds into the water fountain while waiting for Beard Papa's to open one Saturday morning. 


love YBG!!! Such a treat in the middle of tall towers...
author: Teddy d.

description:
While the weather is warm (sadly I think it's gone until next year), Yerba Buena Gardens is a great place to relax.  If you're lucky enough to work nearby, it's relaxing to eat lunch or drink coffee or tea here to get away from the office for a brief while.

Between the trees, fountains, and abundant grassy spaces to recline on, it's a pretty cool place to have near the heart of the city.  There are usually other people here but it's never too crowded which makes it seem lively but still serene at the same time, a tough combination to accomplish.
author: Lemar H.

description:
It's impossible not to love this place when it's your minor distraction at work. AND when you work on the 8th floor of San Frannie's radest buildin' 

I love watching all the human ants scurry around the green, wade in the waterfall, and muck about the Gardens. And as people are already mentioning, it is a dynamic city green space nestled in the heart of East SOMA like a .. well I want to say baby milking... but that's so raunchy. So, I wont.
author: Andrew C.

description: I used to come here and read a book for my assignments from CCSF on a regular basis. The sound of the waterfall and it flows in the background provides a nice, comfortable atmosphere for me to read. It's neat that they have tables if you walk up a little bit from the waterfall area where you can play chess although I've never seen anyone using them. The park is lit up prettily during night also. Sort of a picturesque setting that can be put on a postcard.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
This is a great place to come during the work day. I grab a quick bite and head over here with everyone else at lunch time. What a great public space. Very well maintained, except for the bathrooms. I try to wait until I get back to work! 
I had lived here two months before I made it over here. Now I look forward to it everyday. Makes the  very tight city a little better to have such great open space!
author: Lisa A.

description:
I was in art school when the renovations and groundbreaking of Yerba Buena Gardens took place. The nearby church was in dire need of repair at that time as well. My life-drawing class would frequently take place here - some old sketches I recently came across had young seedlings staked in place and minimal people moving about about.

Nice to see how much this has become the center for the region...and that the trees are all grown up.
author: Tanya P.

description:
