after catching a movie at the Metreon... take a stroll to the Yerba Buena Gardens and scope out the art, the gardens, the playground (oh, how fun the slides were... just make sure you have slippery butts to fully enjoy the slides... friction is not your friend... play music on the pipe xylophone... dangle on the jungle gym), the Zeum museum (oooh muZeum... i just got that)... the carousel, and the Urge--this wonderful sculpture consisting of a metallic globe with a half-man/half-woman metal person standing on it.  When you sit on the bench that is directly across this sculpture, hydraulic action will cause the metal person to sit down with you!  When you stand up, it will stand up too.  

please appreciate this place... thousands of less-fortunate SF residents were displaced as low-income housing were demolished to make room for the Yerba Buena Gardens!
author: Grace M.

description:
So much fun to live so close to a great park, and a wonderful way to spend a free day, by yourself and with friends!

I really love walking across the street, plopping down on a blanket, relaxing, and reading on a beautiful sunny San Francisco day here. For me, its a closer alternative than Golden Gate and way more central to other establishments I like to frequent!
author: Yelper A.

description: One of my favorite moments in Yerba Buena Gardens is during a sunny afternoon during lunch or even mid-afternoon and seeing all the people on the lawn soaking up every bit of warmth they can. It's a great place to find calm in the middle of the city.
author: Madeline R.

description:
Today was the second time this week that I had lunch at Yerba Buena Gardens.

If it's sunny and warm outside, get your lunch to go and come here to eat. Seriously. All the cool kids are doing it.
author: Richard T.

description: I've spent many an afternoon here when my daughter was younger. A great place to stop for a little break and have the kids let off a little steam in between errands. This place has saved my sanity on numerous occasions. Lots to look out and plenty of place to sit or play.
author: Michele H.

description: I've been here several times and each time was relaxing and enjoyable. Nice place to chill, talk, read a book, or shoot photos. The Martin Luther King Jr. memorial is beautiful and makes for great photo-op's. It's also refreshing to see quotes in different languages embossed on the walls.  The architecture is great and the view from all surrounding streets are beautiful. Lovely place.
author: Maricel B.

description:
Now that summer is here, there is no excuse to sit inside anymore...  well, besides to Yelp about all the places that you've sat outside at, but I digress so let's continue.. 

Yerba Buena is one of my favorite places to sit outside and eat my lunch. With it's great location, you can grab food from neighboring spots (Metreon court, Samovar, the Japanese spot.. etc) and turn it into a picnic.

The soothing sounds of the waterfall and the bright rays of the sun shining down make this place a great escape from the hustle and bustle of downtown.. and there are plenty of opportunities to relax & people watch at Yerba Buena since it's always scattered with people laying out on their blankets, jackets, or bare backs.

Last Saturday, I was pleasantly surprised to find out that there are free outdoor music shows, too! Check it out (http://www.ybae.org/).  Not to mention the other surprise of 10+ people casually bicycling across the grass in their birthday suits... Oh San Francisco..

Although it is small in size, Yerba Buena definitely has a lot to offer and shouldn't be overlooked on your next trip downtown.
author: kat a.

description:
The Yerba Buena Gardens wasn't exactly what I thought it would be. I imagined tons of flowers and small dirt paths, maybe a little pond in the middle. It was more of a concrete garden if you ask me. There is a beautiful waterfall, great views of the city, lots of big trees, some nice art sculptures, a big grassy area in the center, a restaurant and tea house above the waterfall, and tons of birds! Even though it wasn't exactly what I imagined it was still a very nice place to sit around and have some lunch while people watching. We didn't get a chance to check out the restaurant or tea lounge but I definitely want to go back and try out some tea.
Check out what else I had to say about the gardens and SOMA at http://bit.ly/iPFWq I also posted some good pics there as well!
author: Casi C.

description:
This place brings back so many memories of the stupid shit I used to do before I reached my 20's. Brown baggin on a Saturday afternoon with friends, parlaying talking about stuff that in retrospect was never that important. I would always come here and marvel at the MLK waterfall and go underneath it and read the writing on the wall, I think it was the first place I had seen named after Dr. King that wasn't a street or high school. 

The rest of the park is really nice as well. There is plenty of space to lay out , there is a small performance area...you can sit out above the waterfall and marvel at the tall buildings in SF and as Drue C said, look at the evolution of architecture within the city. People keep to themselves, fun place for a picnic or any kind of date when the weather is nice, the MOMA is just seconds away. I suppose the only bad thing is that the metreon is right next door.
author: James J.

description: Great hour or two chill in the park space with a good view of the city. Nice and relaxing. Not too many weird panhandlers. Definitely check out the decorative gardens on the north (west?) end and the waterfall.
author: Celeste T.

description: I took my boys (4 and 1.5 yrs) on an adventure into San Francisco from Berkeley and we found our way to this excellent playground on a warm Sunday morning in early March. We were treated not only to great slides and fun play structures, but a fantastic story-time led by a park staffer named Cole who kept a small crew of little ones (including my kids) fully captivated with his accordion playing and dramatic reading of some classic Dr. Suess stories. Definitely recommend!
author: Joshua M.

description:
This weekend I went ice skating for the very first time at Yerba Buena Gardens!!  I LOVED it!  and for my first time ever I didn't fall as much as I thought I would.  
The park is great, lots of things for every one to do; especially kids, but I don't have any of those yet ;)

I'm totally going to be there, like every weekend!!  LOL!
author: Regina B.

description: I really enjoy after catching an early movie at the AMC theater (because its super cheap!!) to come out to the Yerba Buena Garden and just walk around or take a seat. I have seen people reading, sun bathing, doing some martial arts, or have some EMTs in training come up to you and ask to check your vitals for practice.
author: Justin C.

description: Love this park!  Wish they would allow dogs though... sigh. :-(  I guess too many dog owners don't pick up after their dogs - noone like to sit in poop!
author: Joie d.

description: This is so far one of my favorite places in SF.  It is usually sunny over there, and it's really pretty and green.  Great place to have a picnic or just lay around and read a book.
author: Laura K.

description:
If you sit here -- surrounded by sunshine, blossoming flowers, a glistening waterfall and the gleaming array of downtown SF skyscrapers -- while doing research for a job application, you will have such a great afternoon that you won't even care when you don't end up getting the job after all. 

Who needs a stinking job when you have a free park and beauteous weather and all the time in the world to enjoy it?
author: John G.

description:
I'd give this ONE star if it weren't for the events the Gardens staff hosts regularly. Because of that, this park is put to actual use-- you can drop by and be part of the smily audience because of that.

That's pretty much it for this "oasis in a concrete jungle." The towering Metreon, practically menacing over this venue, threatens to hoarde all its fans. 

All in all I wish this park was put to better use.
author: Carl Z.

description:
This gorgeous interactive park is such an oasis in the middle of the concrete jungle.
It's always beautiful and teeming with good energy, whether you catch it freshly showered and groomed in the morning before all the crowds, at lunchtime to calm your hectic mid-afternoon attitude, or in the evening to silhouette against the comingled architecture in the fading sunset. 
*Easter Egg* There's a statue of a skeletal structure on top of a globe (somewhere by the renovated carousel). Sit on the bench in front of it and find out what happens.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Lovely little spot but what's the use of a park that won't let you chuck a ball around?
Still, good view and impeccable bathrooms.
author: Mer S.

description:
WOW!

A great place to bring your lunch and sit down on the grass/bench.  Gorgeous views of the city high rises and archetecual designs within Yerba Buena Gardens. 

I came here during my lunch break on Election Day 2009 and they had 2 large projection TV's on a trailor...awesome! and GOBAMA!

Plus it's a good place for me to take a litto nap during the workday.
author: Elliot Y.

description: This is a great place to go if you have time to sneak out of the office and take a nap.
author: M O.

description:
I'm not a huge park person, but I love the Yerba Buena Gardens.  It's not a typical park or garden, because there's so much to see and do in the area.  There are spots of pure tranquility to enjoy an impromptu picnic with someone special.  There are sculptures and art pieces that are scattered all around.   It's the perfect 'park' scene for a city girl like me.

Look for the man sitting on the globe.  That's all I'm going to say.
author: Denise M.

description:
Gorgeous place to run around and find sculptures and water fountains. 
I should have a picnic here one day.
On a Sunday afternoon it was pretty laid back, not highly populated. 
They also have WiFi (which might be good during the weekday for some worky).
author: Sari G.

description:
Yerba Buena is a nice space hampered by its surroundings & the fact that it's run like a corporate business park that happens to be open to the public.

First off, Sony City, the odious freakin' Metreon, is right next door - which to me, is a drawback.

Also, the main space of the park adjoins a really busy part of Mission, and downtown these days, there always seems to be a jackhammer blasting on a construction site somewhere nearby.

That being said, it is an isle of (relative) tranquility amidst an otherwise urban milieu.  (Sounding pretty erudite, if I may say.)

Dig: close access to MOMA (across 3rd) & the Centers for the Arts, cleanliness of facilities (which you'd expect at this sort of place), and lots of stuff for kids (and bored adults) to do (ice rink, bowling alley, carousel in the other part of the park across Howard) - if you're into that sort of thing. 

Don't dig: the inescapable sounds of traffic, construction, etc., the smell of that chlorinated(?) water in the waterfall and pools, the people who are only there because they're taking a smoke break from playing video games at the Metreon, and the feeling that you can't really do anything beyond sit quietly here (i.e. no ball/ frisbee throwing, skating, pets, playing of music, etc.) without being asked to stop/ leave.

I'm realizing that by piling on this place, I may sound a little harsh, but I'm very demanding of my parks.

Also, this is also the only place I've ever been shat on by a bird - seagull got me on the hand, and I'm still looking for the bastard so I can return the favor.
author: Ryan W.

description:
GO OUTSIDE!  

Words don't explain the fun and kidisms you'll feel coming here.  You'll get to play tag and remember, dont step on the tanbark aka.the molten lava.

People stay indoors too much.. 

It's a sin..
author: Ray W.

description: it's good to just sit there and enjoy the sunlight with the breeze
author: Changwei H.

description:
Even though a bumblebee chased me from bench to bench last week, Yerba Buena is still one of my favorite places to read a book and enjoy the nice weather. 

However, if I ever find that bee...*grumbles*
author: Nathalie L.

description:
I pass by the Yerba Buena Gardens every time I go to class at the UC Berkeley extension and it is quite beautiful on a bright summer day. There is a wide array of things for anyone to do. From a tourist to a native San Franciscan, it's a nice little getaway from all of the shopping you've done or that well deserved break from the daily grind. It's situated right across the street from the SF MOMA so you are guaranteed a nice place to kotch after a nice stroll through the museum. If you get bored, you can sit and draw the different structures surrounding the area or you can lean up and watch the water flow from the waterfall below Samovar restaurant. 

Again, I give this place a 5 stars because it didn't always look this fabulous and visit-able before. It is well maintained and there is so much to do before and/or after you sunbathe or finish your book as you lay on the manicured grass.
author: Dorothy S.

description:
Fountain, Fountain, and Fountain

Have you ever sat out here on a nice day, the sun in it's full glory, the wind blowing and that wonderful water fountain coming down and splashing unto itself.  This place can be very magical and calming.  

Come down at lunch time and again in the evening.  Each time of day brings a different feeling to this little oasis in the city.
author: Scott P.

description:
The pathways on the Mission Street side have this excellent faux-wild-animal-tracks effect built into them. 
Actually, the park is FULL of weird little touches that make it an engrossing place to spend an afternoon. 
(check out the 'no humans" [pro-butterfly habitat ] sign in the same vicinity)... 
Spring-summer-fall the place is great & the lawn & waterfall are a welcome oasis in the middle of all that downtown concrete... 
Actually, it is everything Union Square shall Never Be Again...
author: Mark L.

description: I really like Yerba Buena Gardens. Love to lie in the grass and just listen to the waterfall. It's a great place to side-step out of the hustle and bustle of city life. Like a little middle-of-the-city sanctuary. Definitely a nice place to check out if you can spare a few minutes.
author: Brad Y.

description: A great park in the mist of downtown craziness. It's great to come here for lunch and sit in the sun. The Yerba Buena Ln has great restaurants and I love Amber. There are summer concerts during lunch hours often. Tons of places to sit and right around the museums and a great place to take a break in general. There is even a playground closer to the Ice Skating Rink and Bowling for kids. I love the waterfalls, the art work all mixed in with trees and greenery. So calming.
author: Natasha M.

description: The best park downtown by far and right by the Metreon, Union Square, and Wesfield Mall. Lots of places to people watch. Benches all around on asphalt or just lay in the well maintained grass. There are a lot of homeless that like to wander around here. I think it's a popular place for them to sleep, but most are doing just that and not begging for money. Love this park!
author: Chris I.

description: I used to come here before the behemoth of the metron was built & could spend hours hangin out & reading the MLK Jr quotes under the waterfall.  Quite the experiance. A pic-nic in the middle of the work day recently had me falling in love w/ YBG all over again.  My friends visiting from Spain had a fabulous time...they said the atmosphere reminded them a little of home.
author: Liz V.

description:
Three stars because I just don't know exactly how I feel about the bowling center at YBC.

It's like this: I like to bowl. It's very relaxing, and since my shoulder is totally trashed, it's as close as I can come to recapturing my glory days as a pitcher (because the similarities between bowling and being on the mound are remarkably similar).

On one hand, I love that a bowling alley is something you can actually find in this part of SF. On the other hand, I hate how these lanes are almost exclusively geared towards kids.

Sure, the lanes are a great place for the young'uns and birthday parties. But it is disappointing that you can't get a lane on a rainy afternoon because the ENTIRE place is booked. 

My other option, of course, would have been to schlep across town to the Presidio, but on a rainy afternoon, driving or catching a bus (as compared to walking a few blocks) simply didn't seem worth the trouble.
author: Derek R.

description: Yerba Buena Gardens is a really cool urban oasis.  You can just relax on the grass, set up a picnic or play at the playground.  There are also several things you can do for $$ such as bowling, ice skating, eating, watching a movie or drink tea at the tea house.  It's centrally located to public transportation and near Moma for all you art lovers.
author: Yi Z.

description: The climbing structures are more appropriate for kids 3 years and up, but my two-year-old also had fun running around the entire YBCA grounds. There actually isn't much here as a "playground" (Noe Valley Rec Center is better), but it is enclosed so that parents can sit down and take a break. And it's right next to the Zeum, carousel, etc.
author: Rob T.

description:
BOWLING ALLEY REVIEW:


 Celebrated my 28th birthday at the rinky-dink bowling alley at YB Gardens.I just want to warn you, you probably don't need a reservation for this place even with a big crowd. I wanted to make sure we had alley's so I booked two and 5 people can play at a time, it was nearly $300 for 3 hours. It's not as cool as the Presidio bowl cause it's not as noisy, dark, or have tv's that play cute cartoons that make me beet red when I chuck a gutter ball. 

The positives: 
The staff let us stay until we finished our last game before we gave up the shoes.
Really clean bathrooms
$3.50 for beer-hey! It's cheaper than a bar and I get to bowl too!
It's fun.
author: nina B.

description:
The children's playground is awesome.  It kept my niece occupied for three hours.

Really pretty.  I enjoyed walking around with my niece.  She loved the waterfalls.
author: Mary F.

description: I love walking over here for lunch and enjoying the peaceful setting.  IT seems like everyone is always enjoying themselves, or just happy to be on a break for whatever they were doing.
author: Levi B.

description:
What can be said about this place? Other than it's a fantastic place to be..

If you had to visit a park in the city, it has to be this one..

Yerba Buena has a wonderful 'Esplanade', which is generally the hub of the park..
It's a big land of nice grass and little hill, one of the many great spots to just hang out..

Also home to some cool events, from festivals to live performances..

Besides the wonderful Martin Luther King Memorial water fountain/fall,  you are surrounded by many great places to visit: The Metreon complex, St Patrick's Church, Yerba Buena Center of the Arts, SFMOMA, The San Francisco Centre less than a block away..
And it's right there with the Moscone Center, so after some conference action, Yerba Buena Gardens is the best way to just rest..

Not to mention the 'other' part of the gardens can be found across the street (via bridge) full of fun, either for kids at the little-big (mainly big) playground and the interactive 'Zeum', to fun for all ages at the bowling alleys and skating rink..

From a person who frequents the gardens every week, this is the place to meet up, and also lie down..

-Nymo's 100% Approval-
author: Nicolo T.

description: One of my favorite places to relax at when I'm downtown. I went today after having a few hours to kill before work - just sat, people watched, and enjoyed the nice warm September weather. The waterfall is a nice area to cool off. You could argue that more shade would be nice but I kind of like the empty grass area just to feel the sun around you. It's just so relaxing here, I love it!
author: Devy E.

description:
San Francisco has a little bit of everything for anyone and everyone. If you like to drink and party yourself till the break of dawn, the clubs all around the city are pretty good. Concerts are held everywhere including the Warfield and American Music Hall. 

San Fran also has it's parks. Yerba Buena is more of an park in the city than Golden Gate Park (which is really another world inside the city like Central Park in NYC). But on glorious day or night, it's nice place to chill and enjoy the city around you. The Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial is an interesting sight amongst the skyscrapers and the Metreon. There the Zeum for the kiddies, Yerba Buena Theater for the Arts, food and the aforementioned Metreon.

If you can't tell, I love this place because it's a short walk from FiDi and the hectic SOMA. It's a place to relax, reflect and enjoy the sights and sounds of the city and the people around you.
author: Stan H.

description:
The sunshine is beckoning so I quickly purchase some steamed milk from the coffee franchise that everyone loves to hate and head outside. I sit on the low wall at the edge of the park to soak in the warmth. It is a beautiful day outside. A man wishes me a happy Easter and I respond in kind. he's obviously a street person. I reply to his questions and have a short conversation with him. When he asks me for money I explain to him that I don't give money to people. I speak to him as I would to anybody else, treating him with the respect and dignity that he deserves as a human being but I won't give him any money. he's quite insistent that I should give him some so I simply tell him that I work too hard for what I have to support someone else's lifestyle. And then I tell him that he should ask someone else.

It's really a shame that in such a beautiful city with so many resources that episodes like this are so commonplace. It's inhumane to let people live like this. We all know that these people have problems - addiction and unmedicated psychosis mainly. And I'm sympathetic to their situation. I used to be very generous. I've since made the decision that I'll no longer enable them through my financial contributions. But I digress...

I walk the circumfrence of Yuerba Buena Gardens. For the uninitiated, there are actually no gardens here. But there is shrubbery around the perimeter of the park where today a young family is staging an easter egg hunt, both parents giving their little ones hints in spanish about where to look. I've always wondered where people living in the city hunted for easter eggs, not having a yard of their own. 

There's a stage off to one end, and various fountains that purl and churn what a sign calls "nonpotable" and I suspect heavily chlorinated water. On one hand, it's aesthetically pleasing. But only if you can avoid noticing that certain areas of the pools have been fenced off because the city's large contingent of crackheads, drunks and derilects make a habit of turning any small body of water into their own personal Roman Baths. And despite my senses being assailed by the crowing and whooping of a nearby enclave of men of this social set, shaggy and leathery from exposure, I make believe that this is an unspoiled urban oasis and snap a few polaroids.
author: Alison P.

description:
Wouldn't recommend that place...unless you have nothing else to do in the city, which never happens.
I tried the place tonight and I must admit that it is not worth the money you pay for it.
On the good side, they do serve beer...
author: Julie D.

description:
This is where I go to work on my sunburn. It's the best little tranquil spot downtown to eat my lunch, lay on the grass. Pretty much every sunny weekday, I'm here. All the noises of Mission and 3rd streets are drowned out.

One of my favorite YB park moments came after a trip to DC and I was lamenting the uniformity there and revelling in my return to SF. On the other side of the park was a woman in an old Metallica t-shirt doing tai chi. Nearby was a business-ish woman stripped down to her bra and underwear sunning her self. Fantastic.
author: reb f.

description:
I love the Yerba Buena Gardens!!! Way back when there was a Discovery Channel Store, I would have my lunch or breaks in the park.  Theres always an interesting mix of people hangin' out in the park.  A snobby drug rep here on a convention from  their drug company from Texas, employees from the Meteron having a smoke break, the stinky, passed out bum laying down in the grass,  the two goth girls cutting class and smoking a bowl near the trees....ah yes, what a great place to people watch.  
I love the waterfalls that you can sit by, the cool rocks you can sit on as well, and all the fairs that they have.  They have the Filipino fair, (mmmm pancit.....) the asian cultural fair( m,mmmm...spring rolls), as well as there is always some band playing some kind of music, especially in summertime
author: Janet R.

description:
This is the poster-park for privately owned public facilities - I think it's the only park in this city that is completely FREE FROM DOG SHIT! You can actually sit comfortably almost anywhere and not feel like a pooch magnet just for eating a sandwich on the grass.

because they actually have funding for such things, the grounds are meticulously maintained and I love watching throughout the year as the plants and flowers change.

I wish they would do more for MLK Day but under the waterfall they do manage to stretch that day out to an entire year...

author: Fong L.

description: From Israel in the gardens, movies at the Metreon, to the MLK  JR waterfall walk, Yerba Buena gardens have provided me with hours of enterainment, beauty, and of course, a relaxing spot for lunch. I am very fortunate to work across the street. I have enjoyed many a Gyros here, and intend to enjoy many more
author: Harry K.

description:
yerba buena garden is many things to many people. for some, it's a nice little oasis in the middle of the concrete jungle. for others, it's a place where the corporate drones and the homeless feel safe enough to lie down somewhat close to one another and take a snooze. still for others, it's nothing more than an extension of the metreon. however, for me, yerba buena garden is the home of dr. martin luther king jr. memorial. hence the first thing i do is to walk over to the majestic waterfall and pay tribute to dr. martin luther king jr.

dr. king, i didn't know you, but your story and words inspire me. your extraordinary strength and courage under despicable hatred moves me. dr. king, it must have been lonesome at times to carry the pressure and hopes of an entire nation on your shoulders. how did you do it? where did you draw the inspiration? the strength? the wisdom? the vision? the perseverance? dr. king, you are one of my heroes and i am truly humbled to be standing in front your memorial. we have a long way to go and i'm not sure if we'll ever get there, but i do know that without you, we would not be where we are today. so i thank you. may you rest in peace...

for those who are interested:

west entrance king inscription: "no, no, we are not satisfied, and we will not be satisfied until justice rolls down like water and righteousness like a mighty stream."  -- washington d.c 1963 

east entrance king inscription: "i believe that a day will come when all god's children from bass black to treble white will be significant on the constitution's keyboard."  -- san francisco ca, 1956
author: frisco j.

description: This is such a great place to go for lunch during the workday, as well as to take visiting friends and family after a long walk around downtown SF.
author: Jon M.

description: Take an urban stroll with just the right amount of green, sounds of running water, birds alighting, avant-garde planning, design and architecture, playspace for kids, and join the collective basking on sunny days. Working in SOMA or the FiDi, lunchtime can be made much more enjoyable with a view from the upper levels. Go round on the carousel, glide a bit at the ice rink or walk the lengths after tea at Samovar up top. Nice for a little meandering after a date.
author: Ligaya T.

description: We love all this place has to offer!  The playground is spacious, the carousel is 100 years old, the Zeum was very creative and had the parents playing along with the kids.  I love my Dreamy San Francisco.
author: Christy Y.

description: peaceful and serene. This is the perfect spot to de-stress and unwind with a book. Its hard to find such a peaceful spot in the hustle and bustle of San Francisco but its here.
author: Kalvin C.

description: My favorite place to lunch!! My coworkers and I frequent Yerba Buena a few times a week, with our lunches in hand. Its not so much a year-round lunch place, but summers here are the best! From May- October, Yerba Buena hosts concerts & festivals, many of them occurring during the lunch hours! check out the calendar:  http://www.ybgf.org/cgi-local/Calendar/calendar.pl   You're sure to see sunbathers, kiddies on field trips, and corporates looking for serenity. It's a place for everyone to enjoy.......tip: bring some kind of mat or bag, if you have...the grounds are wet & muddy at times! no one in the office wants to wonder what's up w/ your stain.
author: Nicole L.

description: The area is nice.  Alot of people on sunny days.  Have festival here too.  Not good when raining.  Good place to a nap and read in the sun.  Nice view of the sky and surroundings.
author: John F.

description:
hello sunshine, goodbye office!
this place is good for naps, gossiping, eating, crying, and people watching.
4 stars because its nothing, absolutely NOTHING like a garden... there are busy streets on all 4 sides... but at least there are shards of grass that one can concentrate on and block out the 'city'

today was an especially exciting day at the gardens. nothing better than subwaysunbathingthirstythursday!!!!!!!
author: Helen N.

description: I absolutely love going here, its a great way to spend an afternoon relaxing in the city, in some ways it feels like you are outside of the city just walking the grounds with the sound of the waterfall going.  Definitely a nice way to pass the time if you are waiting to see a movie at Metreon or just looking to have the book/picnic thing in the park.  Be sure to check out the Martin Luther King quotes at the Waterfall!
author: Ryan D.

description: Grab your lunch at Specialties and head over on a sunny day to have a nice peaceful lunch with hundreds of other San Franciscans.  It is a great way to unwind at lunch time and people watch all at once.
author: Pele N.

description: Wow. I wish I could say something other people haven't said, but people have pretty much covered it. This is a nice little park with some beautiful, but seriously underappreciated flowers near the waterfall. There are wonderful plays, ballets and live music during the weekend half the year. It is generally pretty peaceful and there are a lot of people tanning in the sun.
author: Jordan M.

description: I come here all the time to eat lunch in shade or sun (where there is some).  Since its the summer now they have free concerts from 12:30 to 1:30.  Last week I saw some opera women from I believe Switzerland and I'm not into opera but they did a beautiful job.  A few days before there were these kids and adults doing some cool interpretive dance, or that was what I was interpreting it as.  So if there is no music you can always stare at people and people watch (sunglasses preferred). They compost at the park which I think is fantastic and the grass is wonderful!
author: Megan L.

description: The waterfall is so hypnotizing... So very hypnotizing. I think I might take my laptop and make this my permanent office. A great urban oasis, for sure.
author: Michael E.

description: A wonderful place to amble during lunch hours downtown, the shop girls and office boys lounging and preening are pretty too.
author: Stellah D.

description: Four words: Books By the Bay! Huge annual bookfair held in beautiful Yerba Buena Gardens during the summer. Couldn't be a nicer location.
author: Jude F.

description: A very nice park. Lovely fountains. If you visit San Francisco you need to visit
author: Jay T.

description: Spots to hang out in the sun (concrete to sit upon), spots in the shade to snooze in, a waterfall, Metreon and SFMOMA all within a stone's throw. Do not try to walk on the rock "islands" in the waterfall as the security camera will catch you and an angry security guard will tell you to get out!
author: Alden C.

description: I don't feel like I am going to accidentally sit in dog poop or some sort of drinking-in-the-park mess when I lounge here. Spend the day in the sun with occasional music, or the sounds of the waterfalls nearby.
author: Taylor S.

description:
one sunny and warm day i was laying out to get some sun.  while lying on my stomach one of them little black birds landed on my back.  kinda scared me at first but afterwards i couldn't stop laughing about it.  pretty funny.
it's nice to have a park in the middle of the city...
author: charlotte s.

description:
plus one star for having a park throwing distance from my loft.
plus one star for all the fun waterfalls
plus one star for being part of the revitalization of SOMA
plus one star for being the shortcut on the way home from my gym
plus one star for the park being kept really clean by the staff
minus one star for said staff forbidding playing frisbee in the park
author: D S.

description: Beautiful and clean without being sterile. A modern, urban cityscape kind of park.
author: Caroline C.

description: When my bro came to visit from out of town with my little niece, I thought it appropriate to bring him here where sure enough, they had a great time! The backdrop to this place is pretty cool considering the playground is nestled amidst skyscrapers. What I enjoy most is that it 's an enclosure that is safe and tailored so that the kids can run rampid all the while the adults can chill  keeping an eye out. Plenty of things to do in and around this little haven. If you haven't been, come and check it out!
author: Dennes H.

description: I've walked by this hidden jewel many times during my rushed hour at lunch.  I finally got to see this gem in the city during the Pistahan festival.  It was so much fun!  What could be better than a great park in the middle of the city and some lumpia and halo halo?!  Parking is spendy, so if you can take public transportation to a festival, I highly recommend it.
author: San D.

description: This is a nice place to stroll around and check out the waterfall in the middle of SOMA.  The Metreon is here, along with a bowling alley, ice skating rink, Zeum, a carousel, and a few other things.  I live walking distance from here, so I find myself passing through regularly.  Sometimes, there are events and concerts in the park, which is nice.  The closest parking is a paid lot directly across the street from the Metreon.  This is a place for the entire family.
author: Ryan W.

description: This little park makes SOMA feel like a real neighborhood. People gather here to sip smoothies, wait for their movie at the Metreon, make their lunch breaks last and watch their kids play at the sweet play structure. It sits above the Moscone convention center and is thus above the noisy traffic below. The scent of flowering trees in the the early spring makes you feel all romantic and stuff. It is worth climbing the stairs up to this little paradise so you don't have to walk along 4th.
author: Julie D.

description:
- yerba buena means "good herb"
whenever i show up to work a little early, i sit in the park and enjoy the sun. they've got waterfalls, fountains, trees, rocks, butterflies, birds grass and sometimes live music for free!  the "yerba buena gardens festival" lasts pretty much from spring to summer and they've got some pretty good acts.  
   to me it's a little weird to have security guards in the park to tell you not to skate or bike around. they recently started wearing red shirts/jackets (in case you didn't notice). i've never really been harassed by them though, so that's cool.
author: Pflip W.

description: Oh, how I miss getting my sandwich at Specialty's and going to sit on the grass at Yerba Buena for a little one-person picnic. It was the most beautiful escape from the office that I could have asked for. If you work within a five-block radius, you must spend at least one lunchtime here soon.
author: Cheshire I.

description:
Yerba Buena is a metropolitan oasis. I work about 3 blocks away. Sometimes I walk over to get some fresh air and forget about the stress of the work day.

Lots of green space to lounge and lot's of benches and places to sit and eat. You get a wonderful view of the Moma and other downtown structures modern and traditional mixing cohesively. I've never been but there's some nice cafes above.

The waterfalls and rivers running around the structure make for a serene soothing experience. I hope the person who designed this achieved some accolades. If so they were well deserved.

One thing. A sea gull shit on my back during a beautiful lunch one afternoon. But that's what a great place it is. It just rolled off my shoulder.
author: Brian J.

description: One of my favorite little parks in San Francisco.  It's not the most nature-laden, but I love the multiple levels, all the places to sit, the people watching--especially the kids, the surrounding skyline, the little red brick church across the street whose bells toll at what are to me odd times...and I love that fountain for some reason.  Good place for a book, a coffee, and a sunny day.
author: Kevin S.

description: This is what I like about where I live. A little garden in the middle of the big bad city. Almost perfect, if not for the homeless, or the thugs that come out on weekends for the movies at the Metreon. Or all the little geek clones with their plastic bags and convention badges around their necks, or...OK, now I'm just being bitter. Seriously, without all of the above, this wouldn't be a garden in the middle of SF, it would be Idaho. And I wouldn't want to live here.
author: Johnny O.

description: Nicer than Union Square on a Sunday when the weather is warm. Go read the words of Martin Luther King Jr. behind the flowing fountain and meditate on the concept. Generally visiting musical groups will have a concert around noon on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday in the Summer. It is pretty random.
author: miriam b.

description: Nice spot to smoke a doobie, hypothetically. Also a nice spot to soak in some rays and converse within a downtown environment.
author: Nate L.

description: Yerba Gardens is like an oasis, a sight for sore eyes really, after spending hours of shopping and walking in the busy streets of downtown. Tucked behind the Metreon, YBG is literally fresh year round, from the flowers to its outdoor events. Every mid-August check out "Pistahan"- a free festival celebrating Filipino arts and culture.
author: Leroid D.

description: A great place to hangout, walk around, and have a good time with your friends! Lovely on a sunny day! Whatever you do take it all in!
author: Mel P.

description: The Yerba Buena Gardens are one of the best parts of downtown San Francisco! Plenty of benches, meandering pathways, gorgeous waterworks, and lots of grass whether you're looking for shade or sun. There's no better place to recover from a late night out, excessive shopping, or just too much wandering around SoMA and the FiDi.
author: Will A.

description: YEAH!!!!!! This place is really awesome. The waterfall is beautiful. The trees are perfect, especially when you're laying under it and the sun filters through. Ahh... its really fun during the day or at night. The waterfall is better at night, actually, because it's illuminated. WORD OF WARNING: If you sit on top of the waterfall when you're eating a Chipotle burrito and it gets windy, all that water will skim off the waterfall and  spray on you.
author: O K.

description:
samovar is the only redeeming quality of this place. the fountain is nice and peaceful. also the sinking ship sculpture rocks.

other than that, it feels like an old section of disneyland that has been abandoned and overrun by homeless people. the metreon is a horrific waste of space, and the crappy landscaping is kind of painful.

though, I can't really argue against greenery int he concrete jungle.

yipes. well
author: Mark F.

description: I love this playground !! There's a structure with 3 slides , a separate mini slide , and one other structure . The structure with the slides is so cool ! There's 3 slides of different sizes / lengths . I used to LOVE going on the super long one . My cousins and I would line up and go on it again and again . There's also a small maze thing which is cool . I used to love climbing  up and down the sides that look like mini hills that border the park .
author: Eileen L.

description: beautiful space right smack dab in the middle of downtown. The MLK waterfall is inspiring.
author: Jay E.

description: Awesome. This park of sorts first perfectly into the landscape around the SF Moma. The atmosphere, though obviously unnatural, is tranquil like a park. Festivals here are terrific. The architecture, including the waterfalls, is excellent.  San Francisco does everything right.
author: Anonymous P.

description: If  you like urban architectue, Yerba Buena Gardens is a dream. If you like unruly wild growth within nature, pass it up for the parks along the coast. No dogs are allowed here.
author: Judy L.

description: A brilliant family destination in the middle of the city. Great playground, carousel, interesting landscaping, cafes and restaurants, the Metreon movie theater nearby and even a bowling alley and an ice rink.
author: Jenni O.

description: You know that clustered, Blade Runner, Burton Batman Citiopolis look? Subtract the darkness and thats the Gardens, visually stunning, a world class urban park. WIth the Metreon right there, SOMA and so much more it went from being a decade old hole [that's  old school, son] to a new destination spot. Inexpensive parking on Mission between 4th and 5th.Good place to bring vistors.
author: Krishna D.

description: Nice that there is a park in the middle of the city.  But it is still very urban, good and bad.  I like the views of the skyline and all the buildings and that it is so close to the ice skating, bowling, movie theatre, SFMOMA, and all the fun SF things.  But it is not a quite park like some of the larger green spaces in SF.  Still it is cool that they have something green, instead of just a large concrete slab.
author: Julie R.

description:
I sit on the bench, 
look around all the tall buidlings in the financial district, the old church, Jewish museum, people on the grass, and blue sky...
and eat my lunch;)

It is my favorite part of my day!
author: Ritsmomo L.

description: Little something to keep in mind...Within the building that creates the waterfall are some of the cleanest public restrooms in the city.  There are fresh (fresh!) flowers on the counter.  And, I seriously think almost everytime I've been there, I have seen a cleaning/maintenance person on their way in or out.
author: L W.

description: you know what i love about this place?  it's padded.  that and it's a managable size.  so you (the parent) can sit there and see the entire thing.  oh yes, i suppose they could wander out of sight, but you'd know it in short time.  plus the musical stuff is cool.
author: sarah b.

description: A little green among the granite of SOMA!  I love all the water flowing everywhere, the bright green goodness when you've seen all the pavement you can handle, the eclectic crowd, and plenty of leg room whether it be lunch, nap, or lounge.  I will often grab a bite at one of the nearby amazing eateries and head on over.  Feeling a little pale?  I'll sunbathe!  Need to catch up with my pals?  Grab the celly and a bench!  Perfect for any occasion!  Love, love, love it!
author: Tara G.

description: An excellent place for eating lunch and taking a break from looking at your computer screen.
author: katharine s.

description: If I were a rockstar, I'd totally film one of my videos here... Or at least part of it... And if I were a model, I'd totally do a photoshoot here... But I'm not and I'm not... So I have to be content with walking through Yerba Buena and just hanging out here... The waterfall is so pretty, although it does spray a little... And hey, the Metreon is there too...
author: Lindsey S.

description: I go to Everest, which is practically right across the street. And my day wouldn't be complete without a little side-trip to the park. Nearly every morning, I'm there. I like to sit off at the side and watch people, watch them lounge around on the grass even butt-early in the morning like they're nude-bathing at Baker Beach. I love watching kids play and people walk their dogs. It's a relaxing feeling despite the traffic going on just beyond the park. I like the fact that you have a little trail to walk on, and you walk past a patch of flowers that state that only butterflies are allowed to flutter past the petals. How cute is that?
author: Thea G.

description: very peaceful and serene park in the middle of crazy SOMA. i walk through here all the time on my way into the metreon to return movies. i once threw a penny in the fountain and made a wish... sadly, it didn't come true. i still love being here though and listening to the loud crashing of the water fountains throughout the park.
author: Michelle I.

description: one of the best spots to go to for lunch(especially when you have a 2 hour lunch like me). you can sit on the grass, sit on the benches by the pond, sit by the waterfall, etc. there are places to grab some food and there is a starbizucks for those rare warm days. sometimes they have a free concert and it's always conveniently slated for lunch time. yesterday(9/11) was Bayonics and it was awesome. at night, if youre like me, you can come here and drink with a buddy or even get a little freaky nawm mean..
author: Andrew T.

description: pretty fantastic, tranquil park in the middle of the downtown bustle. thanks to rebecca for exposing me to wonderful yerba buena gardens. one carryout lunchtime picnic was all it took to sell me on the beauty of this spot.
author: Marla W.

description: the bf took me here after hrs for a cute stroll. i enjoyed the water fall and architecture structures, very artsy.  i was expecting some transient sleeping all over the place, but nope maybe just 1 or 2, until security told them to leave.  i would totally come back when its sunny and warm.
author: Hana ..

description: fabulous place to take a nap on a nice, sunny day. one little tip: avoid the upper area with the large, long "pool" of water on windy days... it get's misty up there!
author: AJ M.

description: it's funny to me that they call this place yerba buena 'gardens' when i think of it as the lawn attached to the Metreon. it kicks ass for lounging in the sun and making your lunch break seem more like a picnic. last time i was there, i looked up from my lunch to see a troupe of hoola hoopers, my favorite in shiny silver pants... you should really see what one can do with a hoola hoop.
author: heather m.

description: yerba buena garden park for the fun slides and fun in the sun...carousel is cool too....the restaurant on the 2nd floor -located above the ice skating rink is a nice spot for sanwiches..nice view..kind of nuts with soo many kids..but nice option
author: Rob C.

description: I used to come here often when I worked at Moscone Center.  Boy, was that a long ass time ago!  But people watching here is fantastic and once in a while you can catch some events happening.  I love now that it has built up so much more than all those years ago.
author: Misti L.

description: Worst bowling alley I've ever seen.  Ever.  Bad lane conditions, poor service, and even worse overall facilites make this place pretty darn bad.
author: Ed R.

description: i love this place, especially the waterfall/mlk memorial.  great place to chill after going to the moma, or just to eat lunch on a warm, autumn day...
author: Jill k.

description: nice patch of greenery in the middle of the city.  i love picnicing there during lunch.  actually, in the spring/summer- when i have to make phone calls to clients- i do from there. beats being in a cubicle all day.
author: Alan N.

description: Just wanted to remind you folks that San Francisco has some seriously good places just to chill and look around. Go there prepared to open your mind and just look around: the ambient architecture is really impressive. The Sony Center is disappointing: they spent a bomb on that place, and for that money should have employed more imagination. But the rest, including that dinky little church nearby: yeah, worth looking at.  It should make you really really happy you're not in Des Moines.
author: Rowley A.
